text: The following are the requisites of an obligation, except

choices.text: Passive subject, debtor or obligor
Active subject, creditor or oblige
Efficient cause
Demand

explanation: The requisites of an obligation are: (1) passive subject (debtor/obligor), (2) active subject (creditor/obligee), (3) object or prestation, and (4) juridical tie or efficient cause. Demand is not a requisite of an obligation.

text: The person who has the duty of giving, doing or not doing

choices.text: Obligee
Obligor
Active subject
Creditor

explanation: The obligor or debtor is the person who has the duty to give, do, or not do something.

text: The person in whose favor the obligation is constituted

choices.text: Obligor
Obligee
Passive subject
Debtor

explanation: The obligee or creditor is the person in whose favor the obligation is constituted.

text: It refers to the juridical tie or efficient cause that binds the parties to the obligation

choices.text: Obligee
Obligor
Prestation
Vinculum

explanation: The vinculum juris or juridical tie is the legal bond that binds the parties to the obligation.

text: It is an obligation which is based on positive law and gives right to enforce its performance

choices.text: Natural obligation
Civil obligation
Moral obligation
Legal obligation

explanation: A civil obligation is based on positive law and gives the right to enforce its performance in court.

text: Which of the following statements does not pertain to natural obligation?

choices.text: It is not enforceable in a court of justice
Obligation exists by reason of equity and moral justice
If performed voluntarily, recovery can no longer be made
There is juridical necessity to perform it

explanation: Natural obligations are not enforceable in court and there is no juridical necessity to perform them. They are based on equity and moral justice.

text: The duty not to recover what has voluntarily been paid although payment was no longer required

choices.text: Civil Obligation
Natural Obligation
Moral Obligation
Juridical Obligation

explanation: A natural obligation is one that cannot be enforced in court but if voluntarily performed, the payment cannot be recovered.

text: Obligations may arise from any of the following, except

choices.text: Contracts
Quasi-contracts
Law
Prestation

explanation: Obligations may arise from contracts, quasi-contracts, delicts, and law. Prestation is not a source of obligation but rather the object or subject matter of an obligation.

text: The source of an obligation which is a rule of conduct, just and obligatory, promulgated by legitimate authorities for common good, benefit and observance

choices.text: Contracts
Quasi contracts
Delicts
Law

explanation: Law is a source of obligation that consists of rules of conduct promulgated by legitimate authorities for the common good.

text: The duty to pay taxes and to support one's family are obligations arising from

choices.text: Law
Contracts
Quasi Contracts
Delicts

explanation: The obligation to pay taxes and support one's family are imposed by law, not by contract or other sources.

text: It is a source of a civil obligation that refers to a juridical relation which arises from certain lawful, voluntary and unilateral act, to the end that no one may be unjustly enriched or benefited at the expense of another

choices.text: Quasi-delict
Quasi-contract
Contract
Delict

explanation: A quasi-contract is a juridical relation that arises from lawful, voluntary, and unilateral acts to prevent unjust enrichment.

text: Which of the following is not considered as quasi contract?

choices.text: Solution Indebiti
When the third person without the knowledge of the debtor, pays the debt
Negotiorum Gestio
Reimbursement due to a person who saved the property during fire or storm without the owner's knowledge

explanation: The first three options are examples of quasi-contracts. The last option is not a quasi-contract as it involves a voluntary act without the intention to create a juridical relation.

text: When something is received when there is no right to demand it, and it was unduly delivered thru mistake, the recipient has the duty to return it

choices.text: Quasi-contract
Quasi-delict
Negotiorum gestio
Solutio indebiti

explanation: Solutio indebiti is a quasi-contract where something is received when there is no right to demand it, and it was unduly delivered through mistake.

text: When a person voluntarily takes charge of another's abandoned business or property without the owner's authority where reimbursement must be made for necessary and useful expenses

choices.text: Quasi-contract
Quasi-delict
Negotiorum gestio
Solutio indebiti

explanation: Negotiorum gestio is a quasi-contract where a person voluntarily takes charge of another's abandoned business or property without the owner's authority.

text: A fault or act or omission of care which causes damage to another, there being no pre-existing contractual relations between the parties

choices.text: Quasi-contract
Quasi-delict
Negotiorum gestio
Solutio indebiti

explanation: Quasi-delict is a fault or act of negligence that causes damage to another, where there is no pre-existing contractual relation between the parties.

text: It refers to the negligence or fault that is a source of civil obligation wherein a person by act or omission cause damage to another

choices.text: Culpa criminal
Culpa contractual
Culpa aquiliana
Culpa legal

explanation: Culpa aquiliana is the negligence or fault that is a source of civil obligation where a person by act or omission causes damage to another.

text: It refers to a ground for breach of obligation that refers to the deliberate and intentional evasion for the normal fulfillment of obligation

choices.text: Mora or delay
Dolo or fraud
Culpa or negligence
Contravention of the tenor of the obligation

explanation: Dolo or fraud refers to the deliberate and intentional evasion of the normal fulfillment of an obligation.

text: It is a thing that is particularly designated or physically segregated from all others of the same class

choices.text: Generic thing
Indeterminate thing
Determinate thing
Real thing

explanation: A determinate thing is one that is particularly designated or physically segregated from all others of the same class.

text: If a thing refers to a class, to a genus and cannot be pointed out with particularity

choices.text: Generic
Specific
Determinate
Indeterminate

explanation: A generic thing refers to a class or genus and cannot be pointed out with particularity.

text: One of the following is a specific thing

choices.text: Toyota Fortuner car
Mitsubishi Montero Sports car
Isuzu Altera
A Toyota car with engine no. 12345, body no. 6789 and plate no. ABC 123

explanation: A specific thing is one that is particularly designated or physically segregated from all others of the same class. The car with specific engine number, body number, and plate number is a specific thing.

text: Spontaneous products of the soil and the offspring and other products of animals

choices.text: Natural
Industrial
Civil
Penal

explanation: Natural fruits are those produced by nature without human intervention, such as spontaneous products of the soil and offspring of animals.

text: Fruits arising out of contracts - like interest payments

choices.text: Natural
Industrial
Civil
Penal

explanation: Civil fruits are those derived by virtue of a juridical relation, such as interest payments from contracts.

text: Products of the soil through cultivation or intervention of human labor

choices.text: Natural
Industrial
Civil
Penal

explanation: Industrial fruits are those produced by lands of any kind through cultivation or labor.

text: The creditor has the right to the fruits of the thing

choices.text: From the time the obligation to deliver it arises
From the time the fruits have been delivered
From the time there is meeting of the minds
From the perfection of the contract

explanation: The creditor has the right to the fruits of the thing from the time the obligation to deliver it arises.

text: Unless the law or the stipulation of the parties requires another standard of care, the obligation to give a thing carries with it the obligation to take care of it with

choices.text: Extra-ordinary diligence
Degree of care agreed upon by the parties
Diligence of a Good Father of a Family
Diligence of a Good Family of a Father

explanation: Unless the law or stipulation requires otherwise, the obligation to give a thing carries with it the obligation to take care of it with the diligence of a good father of a family.

text: On a certain year, D was obliged under a contract executed on March 1 to deliver an agricultural land to C on April 1. D, however, actually delivered the land and the fruits thereof to C on May 1. The right of C before the delivery, on one hand, and his right after the delivery, on the other hand, of the agricultural land and its fruits, to him are referred to as

choices.text: Personal right and real right, respectively
Real right and personal right, respectively
Both are considered a personal right
Both are considered a real right

explanation: Before delivery, C has a personal right (right to demand delivery). After delivery, C has a real right (right of ownership).

text: What is the term for the delay on the part of the debtor?

choices.text: Mora solvendi
Mora accipiendi
Compensatio morae
Mora obligor

explanation: Mora solvendi is the delay on the part of the debtor in the performance of his obligation.

text: This refers to delay on the part of the creditor

choices.text: Mora solvendi ex re
Mora solvendi ex persona
Compensatio morae
Mora accipiendi

explanation: Mora accipiendi is the delay on the part of the creditor in accepting the performance of the obligation.

text: Which of the following is demand necessary to make the debtor in delay in the performance of his obligation?

choices.text: When the time of performance is of the essence
When the time of performance has been stipulated
When the law so provides
When demand would be useless

explanation: Demand is necessary to make the debtor in delay when the time of performance has been stipulated.

text: Which of the following statements concerning delay is incorrect?

choices.text: There is no delay in obligations not to do
Delay, as a rule, exists, when the debtor does not perform his obligation on the date it is due
Demand, as a rule, is required, in order for delay to exist
When time is of the essence of the contract, delay on the part of the debtor exists despite the absence of demand

explanation: Delay can exist in obligations not to do when the debtor performs the prohibited act.

text: They are damages awarded by the court by reason of physical suffering, mental anguish, fright, serious anxiety, besmirched reputation, wounded feelings, moral shock, social humiliation and similar injury

choices.text: Nominal damages
Exemplary damages
Temperate damages
Moral damages

explanation: Moral damages are awarded for physical suffering, mental anguish, fright, serious anxiety, besmirched reputation, wounded feelings, moral shock, social humiliation and similar injury.

text: Damages awarded to vindicate a right

choices.text: Liquidated
Actual
Nominal
Exemplary

explanation: Nominal damages are awarded to vindicate a right or to recognize a violation of a right.

text: When the exact amount of damages cannot be ascertained

choices.text: Exemplary
Liquidated
Temperate
Moral

explanation: Temperate damages are awarded when the exact amount of damages cannot be ascertained.

text: Statement I The receipt of a later installment of a debt without reservation as to prior installments, shall give rise to a rebuttable presumption that such installments have been paid Statement II If a taxpayer pays his income tax liability for the current year, there is a presumption that tax liability for the previous year has been paid

choices.text: True true
True false
False true
False false

explanation: Statement I is true - receipt of a later installment without reservation creates a presumption that prior installments were paid. Statement II is false - payment of current year's tax does not create a presumption that previous year's tax was paid.

text: Which of the following is not a proper remedy for the creditor?

choices.text: To compel the debtor to make the delivery, if the obligation is to deliver a determinate thing
To ask that the obligation be complied with at the expense of the debtor, if the obligation is to deliver a generic thing
To compel the debtor to perform the obligation, if the obligation is an obligation to do
To ask the debtor that what has been done be undone, if the obligation is an obligation not to do

explanation: For obligations not to do, the proper remedy is to demand that what has been done be undone at the expense of the debtor, not to ask the debtor to undo it.

text: It refers to one of the successive rights of unpaid creditor by exercising the rights of his negligent debtor in order to preserve or recover for the patrimony of the debtor the product of such actions, and then obtain therefrom the satisfaction of his own credit

choices.text: Levy by attachment and execution the property of the debtor
Accion subrogatoria
Accion pauliana
Action for damages against third persons who acquired the debtors property in bad faith

explanation: Accion subrogatoria is the right of the creditor to exercise the rights and actions of the debtor to preserve or recover the debtor's patrimony.

text: D is obliged to give C P10,000 if X dies. This is an example of

choices.text: An obligation with a suspensive condition
An obligation with a resolutory condition
An obligation with a period
A pure obligation

explanation: This is an obligation with a suspensive condition because the obligation to give P10,000 will arise only when X dies.

text: Whenever a period is designated in an obligation, the said period shall be presumed to have been established for the benefit of

choices.text: The debtor
The creditor
Both the debtor and the creditor
Neither of the parties

explanation: When a period is designated in an obligation, it is presumed to have been established for the benefit of the debtor.

text: The debtor shall lose the right to make use of the period in the following cases, except

choices.text: When he becomes insolvent
When he violates any undertaking in consideration of which the creditor agreed to the period
When the debtor attempts to abscond
When he does not furnish any guaranty or security to the creditor

explanation: The debtor loses the right to make use of the period when he becomes insolvent, violates undertakings, or attempts to abscond, but not when he fails to furnish guaranty or security.

text: On July 1, 2020, D obliged himself to give C P50,000 if C will marry X on or before December 31, 2020. The condition of the obligation is a

choices.text: Positive condition
Negative condition
Joint condition
Impossible condition

explanation: This is a positive condition because it requires the happening of an event (C marrying X) for the obligation to arise.

text: On July 1, 2020, D obliged himself to give C a specific car if C will not marry X on or before December 31, 2020. The condition of the obligation is a

choices.text: Positive condition
Negative condition
Divisible condition
Impossible condition

explanation: This is a negative condition because it requires the non-happening of an event (C not marrying X) for the obligation to arise.

text: D is obliged to give C a specific car if C passes the CPA Examination. Ds obligation is an example of

choices.text: A pure obligation
An obligation with a suspensive condition
An obligation with a resolutory condition
An obligation with a period

explanation: This is an obligation with a suspensive condition because the obligation to give the car will arise only when C passes the CPA Examination.

text: This obligation is demandable at once when it

choices.text: Has a resolutory condition
Has a suspensive condition
Is with a term ex-die
Has a period

explanation: An obligation with a resolutory condition is demandable at once, but will be extinguished when the condition is fulfilled.

text: A promised to allow B to use his car until the latter becomes a lawyer. What is the type of obligation?

choices.text: Obligation with a suspensive condition
Obligation with a resolutory condition
Obligation ex die or with a suspensive period
Obligation in diem or with a resolutory period

explanation: This is an obligation with a resolutory period because the obligation will be extinguished when B becomes a lawyer.

text: Where two or more prestations have been agreed upon but only one is due, the obligation is

choices.text: Alternative
Facultative
Conjoint
Solidary

explanation: In an alternative obligation, two or more prestations have been agreed upon but only one is due.

text: Where only one prestation has been agreed upon, but the obligor may render another in substitution, the obligation is

choices.text: Alternative
Facultative
Conjoint
Solidary

explanation: In a facultative obligation, only one prestation has been agreed upon, but the obligor may render another in substitution.

text: In alternative obligation, the right of choice belongs to

choices.text: The creditor
The debtor
Both the creditor and the debtor
Third person

explanation: In an alternative obligation, the right of choice belongs to the debtor, unless it has been expressly granted to the creditor.

text: In facultative obligation, the right of choice belongs to

choices.text: The creditor
The debtor
Both the creditor and the debtor
Third person

explanation: In a facultative obligation, the right of choice belongs to the debtor.

text: One of the distinctions between a facultative obligation and an alternative obligation is that in an alternative obligation

choices.text: Only one thing is principally due
The right of choice belongs to the debtor alone
If the obligation to give a principal thing is void, the obligation to give the substitute is also void
If all presentations except one are impossible, that which is possible must still be given

explanation: In an alternative obligation, if all prestations except one are impossible, that which is possible must still be given. This is not true in a facultative obligation.

text: An obligation where various prestations are due but the performance of all of them is required in order to extinguish the obligation is known as

choices.text: Alternative obligation
Facultative obligation
Conjunctive obligation
Simple obligation

explanation: A conjunctive obligation is one where various prestations are due and the performance of all of them is required to extinguish the obligation.

text: Indivisibility as distinguished from solidarity

choices.text: Plurality of subject is indivisible
When the obligation is converted into one of indemnity for damages because of breach, the character of the obligation remains
Refers to the legal tie or vinculum
Refers to the prestation which constitutes the object of the obligation

explanation: Indivisibility refers to the prestation (object) of the obligation, while solidarity refers to the legal tie or vinculum between the parties.

text: It refers to a joint obligation

choices.text: One in which each debtor is liable for the entire obligation, and each creditor is entitled to demand the whole obligations
One in which either one of the parties is indispensable or the other is not necessary
One in which the obligation of one is a resolutory condition of the other, the non-fulfilment of which entitles the other party to rescind the contract
One in which each of the debtors is liable only for a proportionate part of the debt and each creditor is entitled only for a proportionate part of the credit

explanation: In a joint obligation, each debtor is liable only for his proportionate share of the debt, and each creditor is entitled only to his proportionate share of the credit.

text: Which of the following is not a conditional obligation?

choices.text: D to give C P1,000 if C passes the examination
D to pay C P1,000 if he has the means
D to give C a horse if C marries X
D is to use Cs car until C returns from Davao

explanation: This is an obligation with a period, not a conditional obligation. The return of C from Davao is a future and certain event that will terminate the obligation.

text: A is obliged to give B her college ring. If she fails to do so, she must give P10,000. This is

choices.text: Alternative obligation
Conjoint obligation
Facultative obligation
Obligation with a penal clause

explanation: This is an obligation with a penal clause because it provides for a penalty (P10,000) in case of non-performance of the principal obligation (delivery of the college ring).

text: Consider the following statements I. The nullity of the principal obligation carries with it the nullity of the penal clause II. The nullity of the principal obligation does not carry with it the nullity of the penal clause III. The nullity of the penal clause carries with it the nullity of the principal obligation IV. The nullity of the penal clause does not carry with it the nullity of the principal obligation

choices.text: Statements I and III are true
Statements I and IV are true
Statements II and III are true
Statements II and IV are true

explanation: The nullity of the principal obligation carries with it the nullity of the penal clause, but the nullity of the penal clause does not carry with it the nullity of the principal obligation.

text: In which of the following is the debtor still liable despite the fortuitous event causing the loss of the thing?

choices.text: The thing lost is a specific thing
The performance of the obligation has become impossible
The nature of the obligation does not require the assumption of risk
When the law or the obligation expressly so provides

explanation: The debtor remains liable despite a fortuitous event when the law or the obligation expressly so provides.

text: There shall be no liability for loss due to fortuitous events in one of the following cases. Which is it?

choices.text: When the debtor commits delay
When the parties so stipulated that there shall be liability even in case of loss due to fortuitous events
When the nature of the obligation requires the assumption of risks
When the obligation is to deliver a determinate thing and there was no stipulation as to the liability of the debtor in case of loss due to fortuitous events

explanation: In this case, the debtor is not liable for the loss of a determinate thing due to a fortuitous event, unless there was a stipulation to the contrary.

text: The act of offering the credit or what is due him together with a demand that the creditor accept the same

choices.text: Application of payment
Tender of payment
Datio in solutum
Cession

explanation: Tender of payment is the act of offering the credit or what is due together with a demand that the creditor accept the same.

text: Where a debtor transfers all his properties not exempt from execution in favor of his creditors so that the latter may sell them and thus apply the proceeds to their credits

choices.text: Dation in payment
Cession
Application of payment
Consignation

explanation: Cession is the transfer of all properties not exempt from execution by the debtor to his creditors for the purpose of applying the proceeds to their credits.

text: Where a property is alienated to the creditor in satisfaction of a debt in money

choices.text: Dation in payment
Payment by cession
Application of payment
Consignation

explanation: Dation in payment is the alienation of property to the creditor in satisfaction of a debt in money.

text: If the creditor to whom tender of payment has been made refuses without just cause to accept it, the debtor shall be released from responsibility by

choices.text: Assignment of property
Adjudication or dacion en pago
Consignation of the thing or sum due
Condonation

explanation: Adjudication or dacion en pago is the release of the debtor from responsibility when the creditor refuses to accept the payment without just cause.

text: Consignation alone without tender of payment is sufficient in the following cases, except

choices.text: When the creditor is absent or unknown or does not appear at the place of payment
When the creditor presents the title to the oblig ation for collection
When without just cause, the creditor refuses to give a receipt
When two or more persons claim the same right to collect

explanation: Consignation alone without tender of payment is not sufficient when two or more persons claim the same right to collect the property.

text: In tender and consignation, if after consignation is made, the creditor allows the debtor to withdraw the thing deposited in court, which is not true?

choices.text: Co-debtors, guarantors and securities are released from the obligation unless they consented
The obligation remains to subsist
The obligation is extinguished
None of the above

explanation: The obligation remains to subsist even if the creditor allows the debtor to withdraw the thing deposited in court.

text: One of the following is not a requisite of legal compensation. Which is it?

choices.text: That each one of the obligors be bound principally, and that he be at the same time a principal creditor of the other
That the two debts be due
That both debts be liquidated and demandable
That the debts are payable at the same place

explanation: The debts are payable at the same place is not a requisite of legal compensation.

text: The following are the instances of legal subrogation, except

choices.text: When a creditor pays another creditor who is preferred, even without the debtors knowledge
When, even without the knowledge of the debtor, a person interested in the fulfillment of the obligation pays, without prejudice to the effects of confusion as to the latters share
When a property insurance pays the insured in case of loss of the thing insured due to the occurrence of the peril insured
When a third person pays the obligation of the debtor and the latter benefitted from such payment by third person

explanation: Legal subrogation refers to the instances of legal subrogation, except when a third person pays the obligation of the debtor and the latter benefitted from such payment by third person. SITUATIONAL

text: X took a public bus going to his office. Although X paid his fare, the bus conductor did not issue him a ticket. Along the way, the bus met an accident causing a slight injury to X and other passengers. If X is to recover damages from the bus owner, the source of the bus owners liability is

choices.text: Contract
Quasi -delict
Law
P cannot recover any amount because no ticket was issued

explanation: The source of the bus owner's liability is quasi-delict because the bus conductor did not issue X a ticket, which is a breach of duty.

text: X, a customer, drinks a bottle of soft drinks in a restaurant and is hospitalized due to harmful substance in the beverage. Is the manufacturer liable for damages in the absence of contractual relation between them?

choices.text: Yes, because of quasi delict
Yes, because its liability arises out of quasi -contract
No, there being no contract from which liability may arise
Yes, because there is actually a contract between them, the restaurant being the agent of the manufacturer

explanation: The manufacturer is liable for damages in the absence of contractual relation between them because the harmful substance in the beverage is a breach of duty.

text: A passenger on a truck was hurt but in a criminal case against the driver, said driver was acquitted. The victim now sues the owner of the truck for culpa contractual. May the suit still prosper?

choices.text: The victim now sues the owner of the truck for culpa contractual. May the suit still prosper?
No, this will constitute double jeopardy
No, the acquittal means that the guilt of the accused was not proven by proof beyond reasonable doubt
Yes, it is sufficient for him to prove the existence of the contract of carriage and the injuries suffered

explanation: The acquittal means that the guilt of the accused was not proven by proof beyond reasonable doubt, so the suit may not prosper.

text: A owes C P1M. B, without the kno wledge or against the will of A paid C P2M. Can B get reimbursement from A?

choices.text: P2M by way of reimbursement from A to prevent unjust enrichment on the part of A at the expense of B
P1M only for that is the extent of benefit of A
No reimbursement because the payment was not proper being without the knowledge or against the will of A
P1M plus interest from the time of payment until reimbursement

explanation: B can only get reimbursement for the extent of benefit A received, which is P1M.

text: While on the way to deliver a specific diamond ring sold to B and P100,000 in payment of his debt to B, A debtor was robbed. What is the effect of this to his obligation?

choices.text: What is the effect of this to his obligation?
Extinguished as to P100,000 but not as to ring
Extinguished as to ring but not as to P100,000
Not for both as he suffers loss

explanation: The obligation to the ring is extinguished, but the obligation to P100,000 is not extinguished because the debtor suffered loss.

text: While on the way to deliver an 18K diamond ring to B and P100,000 in payment of his debt to B, A debtor was robbed. What is the effect of this to his obligation?

choices.text: What is the effect of this to his obligation?
Extinguished as to P100,000 but not as to ring
Extinguished as to ring but not as to P100,000
Both obligations are not extinguished because generic thing never perishes

explanation: The obligation to the ring is extinguished, but the obligation to P100,000 is not extinguished because the ring is a specific thing.

text: One of the following is a valid obligation. Which is it?

choices.text: D promised to give C P50,000 if C will not swim across the Pacific Ocean
D promised to give C P50,000 if D goes to Canada
D promised to give C p50,000 if C can fly to the moon
D promised to give C P50,000 if C gives him 5 grams of marijuana

explanation: This is a valid obligation because it is a specific and definite promise to give a specific amount of money.

text: One of the follo wing is void obligation

choices.text: D is obliged to give C P5,000 if C does not go to the moon
D is obliged to give C P5,000 if D goes to Baguio
D is obliged to give C P5,000 if C goes to Baguio
D is obliged to give C P5,000 if D wins first prize in the sweepstakes on a ticket that he had already purchased

explanation: This is a void obligation because it is impossible for C to go to the moon.

text: A, B and C bound themselves to deliver to X a specific car worth P3M. Due to the fault of A, the car was lost. In this case

choices.text: X can claim damages from any one of the three for his proportionate part of liability because the obligation is indivisible
X can claim only from A the whole amount of damages other than the value of the car
Since it is solidary liability for damages, X can claim the same from any of the three
Only A is liable for damages although B and C are liable for their respective shares in the obligation

explanation: X can claim damages only from A for the whole amount of damages other than the value of the car.

text: X is obliged to give Y a specific car on July 15, 2020. X did not deliver the car on July 15, 2020. On July 20, 2020, an earthquake destroyed the building where the car was parked, and the car was destroyed. Is X still liable?

choices.text: Is X still liable?
No. Considering that no demand to deliver was made by Y and the specific thing was lost due to fortuitous event, hence the obligation is extinguished
No. The obligation is extinguished, even if the debtor is already in default, because the debtor can plead impossibility of performance
Yes. X is already in legal delay, thus the obligation to deliver the lost specified thing is converted into monetary claim for damages

explanation: The obligation is extinguished because no demand to deliver was made by Y and the specific thing was lost due to fortuitous event.

text: A borrowed money from B payable on December 10, 2021. If A failed to pay on due date, will A be in delay?

choices.text: Yes, because there is stipulation as regards the due date
Yes, if the obligation is in writing
No, because demand has not been made by B
No, if A has the money to pay B

explanation: A will be in delay if he failed to pay on due date, considering there is stipulation as regards the due date.

text: A owes B P150,000 due on August 31, 2020. A executed a mortgage in favor of B on As building to guaranty the obligation. On August 10, 2020, the mortgaged building was totally lost due to an earthquake. On August 12, 2020, B demanded payment from A. Is Bs demand valid?

choices.text: No. The obligation is one with a definite period, thus the creditor cannot demand fulfillment of the obligation before it due
No. The mortgage was extinguished because the object of the contract was lost through a fortuitous event
Yes. The debt becomes due at once because the guarantee was lost although through a fortuitous event, unless the debtor can mortgage another property that is equally satisfactory
Yes. The debts becomes due at once because the periods benefit is given solely to the creditor thereby giving the creditor the right to demand performance even before the due date

explanation: The mortgage was extinguished because the object of the contract was lost through a fortuitous event, so Bs demand is not valid.

text: On July 1, 2020, D obliged himself to give C P50,000 if C will marry X on or before December 31, 2020. Which of the following statements is incorrect?

choices.text: The obligation of D is demandable if C marries X on or before December 31, 2020
The obligation of D is extinguished if it is already January 1, 2021 and C has not yet married X
The obligation of D is extinguished on December 2, 2020 if X dies on the said date and C has not yet married X
The obligation is demandable if C marries X on January 1, 2021

explanation: The obligation of D is extinguished if it is already January 1, 2021 and C has not yet married X.

text: A and B promised to deliver a car valued at P 100,000 to C on or before December 15, 2020. Dec. 15, 2020 came and upon demand by C of delivery from A and B, A is willing to deliver but B refused to deliver. In the case at bar

choices.text: 15, 2020 came and upon demand by C of delivery from A and B, A is willing to deliver but B refused to deliver. In the case at bar
An action for specific performance will lie against both A and B
Both A and B shall be liable for P 50,000 each with damages
A shall be liable for P 50,000 without damages and B shall be liable for P 50,000 with damages

explanation: C can demand delivery of the car from A or B because A is willing to deliver but B refuses to deliver.

text: On May 28, 2020, C demanded the delivery of 100 sacks of rice from D, but D did not comply. The following day, a fire of undetermined origin destroyed Ds warehouse together with about 500 sacks of rice stored therein from which D intended to get 100 sacks of rice for delivery to C

choices.text: Ds obligation to deliver 100 sacks of rice to C is extinguished, the cause of the loss being a fortuitous event
Ds obligation to deliver 100 sacks of rice to C is not extinguished because he can get 100 sacks of rice from other sources
Ds obligation to deli ver 100 sacks of rice to C is not extinguished because D was in default
Ds obligation to pay damages because he was in default

explanation: Ds obligation to deliver 100 sacks of rice to C is extinguished, the cause of the loss being a fortuitous event.

text: A, B and C are obliged to deliver a specific car to X, Y and Z

choices.text: A demand made by X against A, B and C is a valid demand against all the debtors
A demand made by X, Y and Z against A is a valid demand against all the debtors

If a valid demand is made against all the debtors but debtor C cannot comply with his part of the obligation, the obligation is converted into a monetar y obligation to pay the value of the horse plus damages
If the debtors default in their obligation because C is insolvent, A and B will be liable for Cs share of the obligation

explanation: A demand made by X against A, B and C is a valid demand against all the debtors.

text: A owes B who has 5 legitimate children, P50,000 payable on demand on December 31, 2020. Which is correct?

choices.text: If A dies before Dec. 31, 2020, B cannot collect from the heirs of A
If A dies before Dec. 31, 2020, B can collect from the heirs of A
If B dies, his five legitimate children cannot recover from A his obligation
If both A and B die, the heirs of B can collect from the heirs of A

explanation: If A dies before Dec. 31, 2020, B can collect from the heirs of A.

text: D promises to deliver a specific thing to C if the latter will pass the CPA Board Exam. Before the fulfillment of such suspensive condition, D made improvement to the specific thing. Afterwards, C passed the CPA Board Exam. What is the right of D to such improvement of specific thing during the pendency of condition at his expense?

choices.text: D is the owner of such improvement becaus e it was made at his expense
D shall have no other right than that granted to the usufructuary which is the right to enjoy and use the improved determinate thing for a reasonable time
D has the right to retain the improved specific thing by virtue of legal pledge until he was reimbursed by C for the improvement he made on the specific thing
D has the right to ask for reimbursement from C for the improvement he has made on the specific thing

explanation: D is the owner of such improvement becaus e it was made at his expense.

text: Specific performance may not be possible in this civil obligation

choices.text: A, a painter, obliges himself to paint the portrait of B on April 9, 2021
C, a farmer, obliges himself to give his only cow to D on February 14, 2021
E, a veterinarian, obliges himself to give one of his dogs to F on May 1, 2021
G, a registrar of deeds, ob liges himself to effect registration of Hs parcel of land on February 28, 2021

explanation: Specific performance may not be possible in this civil obligation because A is a painter and cannot physically deliver a portrait of B.

text: A owes B sum of money evidenced by a promissory note which has prescribed. X, without the knowledge of A, paid B his debt. Later A reimbursed X for the payment of the latter to B although he has no obligation to do so

choices.text: X, without the knowledge of A, paid B his debt. Later A reimbursed X for the payment of the latter to B although he has no obligation to do so
A can recover his reimbursement to X to prevent unjust enrichment on Xs part at the expense of A
A cannot recover because he has the civil obligation to reimburse X for the latter paid his debt to B
A cannot recover because the payment partakes of natural obligation

explanation: A cannot recover his reimbursement to X because he has the civil obligation to reimburse X for the latter paid his debt to B.

text: D obtained a loan of P1,000 from C who was in his right mind at the time he granted the loan to D. On due date, D paid his obligation to C who has since become insane. Of the total amount received, C lost P700 and spend P300 for his food and other necessary expenses. Which is correct?

choices.text: The total obligation is fully extinguished because C received the payment in full
The obligation is extinguished up to P300 only
The obligation is extinguished up to P700 only
The obligation is voidable subject to legal remedy of annulment

explanation: The obligation is extinguished up to P300 only because C received the payment in full.

text: D is obliged to deliver a specific horse to C for entry in the derby. The day before the agr eed date of delivery, the horse broke its right leg. While it could walk, it could no longer run. Which is correct?

choices.text: The obligation to deliver the horse is not extinguished because the injury to one leg was only considered partial loss
The obligation is extinguished because the injury to the right front leg of the horse is a partial loss that is so important in relation to obligation
The obligation to deliver the horse is not extinguished because the horse could still walk
The obligation to deliver the horse is not extinguished because he can get a horse from other source

explanation: The obligation to deliver the horse is extinguished because the injury to the right front leg of the horse is a partial loss that is so important in relation to obligation.

text: X signs a promissory note and binds himself to pay Y P100,000 plus 15 per annum interest on June 30, 2021. Which statement is correct?

choices.text: Before June 30, 2021, Y can demand payment
If on June 30, 2021 X is paying Y, the latter can refuse payment
X can compel creditor Y to accept payment before June 30, 2021
Because the period is for the benefit of the debtor and creditor, Y can refuse any tendered payment before June 30, 2021

explanation: The period is for the benefit of the debtor and creditor, so Y can refuse any tendered payment before June 30, 2021.

text: X by mistake delivered to A and B a sum of money which should have been delivered to C and D. X now demands the return of the same from A and B. The liability of the latter for the sum of money to which they are not entitled shall be

choices.text: A and B shall be liable s olidarily
A and B shall be liable jointly
They are not liable for having received the money in good faith
X has no right to recover as he was negligent in the delivery of the money

explanation: A and B are liable jointly for the mistake because they are partners in the transaction.

text: X, Y and Z are jointly and severally liable to C for P30,000 which matur es on June 15, 2020. On May 1, 2020, X paid C for the whole amount of the debt. If on December 1, 2020, X will be reimbursed by Y, the latter will be liable for

choices.text: P10,000 with interest from June 15, 2020 to December 1, 2020
P10,000 without interest
P10,000 with interest from May 1, 20120 to June 15, 2020
P10,000 with interest from May 1, 2020 to December 1, 2020

explanation: X paid C for the whole amount of the debt on May 1, 2020. If X is reimbursed by Y on December 1, 2020, Y will be liable for P10,000 with interest from May 1, 2020 to December 1, 2020.

text: X and Y are solidary debtors of A, B, C, and D joint creditors to the amount of P80,000. How much can A collect from X?

choices.text: A could recover P 80,000 from X. A, in turn has to give to B, C and D P20,000 each
A could recover P 40,000 only from X
A could recover P 20,000 only from X
A could recover P 80,000 from X. A, in turn does not have to give to B, C and D P 20,000 each

explanation: A could recover P 40,000 only from X because X is a solidary debtor.

text: A, B and C, solidary debtors, owe solidary creditors X and Y P100,000. X remitted the entire obligation in favor of A. The effect is

choices.text: The obligation is not extinguished until A collects from B and C
The obligation is not yet extinguished until Y is paid by X his share of the credit
A cannot recover from B and C because remission in his favor extend to the benefit of B and C under the princ iple of all for one and one for all
A can recover from B and C their respective share of the debt

explanation: A cannot recover from B and C because remission in his favor extend to the benefit of B and C under the princ iple of all for one and one for all.

text: A borrowed P1M from B and C who acted as solidary creditors. When the loan matured, B wrote a letter to A demanding payment of the loan directly to him. Be fore A could comply, C went to see him personally to collect and he paid him. Did A make a valid payment?

choices.text: No, since A should have split the payment between B and C
No, since B, the other solidary creditor, already made a prior demand for payment from A
Yes, since the payment covers the whole obligation
Yes, since C was a solidary creditor, payment to him extinguished the obligation

explanation: A should have split the payment between B and C, so the payment was not valid.

text: D obliged himself to give C a specific watch, a specific ring, or a specific bracelet. The parties agreed that C will have the right to choose the thing which will be given to him. Before C could make his choice, the watch and the ring are lost through Ds fault, successively. What is the right of C?

choices.text: C may choose the delivery to him of the bracelet, or the price of the watch or the price of ring plus damages
C cannot choose the price of the watch or the price of the ring because the said objects have already been lost
C can only choose to have the bracelet because anyway, D can still perform his obligation
C can only cho ose to have delivery of the bracelet or the price of the ring which was the last item that was lost plus damages

explanation: C cannot choose the price of the watch or the price of the ring because the said objects have already been lost.

text: A owes B P100,000.00 due on October 31, 2020. A executed a mortgaged in favor of B on As building to guaranty the obligation . On October 17, 2020, the building was destroyed by a massive earthquake. On October 18, 2020, B demanded payment from A. Is Bs demand valid?

choices.text: No. The obligation is one with a definite period, thus the creditor cannot demand fulfilment of the obligation before it due
No. The mortgage was extinguished because of the contract was lost even though through a fortuitous event
Yes. The debt becomes due at once because the guarantee was lost even though through a fortuitous event, unless the debtor can mortgage another pe rformance even before the due date

Yes. The debt becomes due at once because the periods benefit is given solely to the creditor thereby giving the creditor the right to demand performance even before the due date Rationale Letter C is the correct answe r but question 40 does not indicate that a fortuitous event occurred.

explanation: The mortgage was extinguished because the contract was lost even though through a fortuitous event.

text: D borrowed P 50,000.00 from C. C dies before he has collected the debt leaving S, his son, as heir. Which of the following statement is correct?

choices.text: S can collect from D although D and C did not agree that the right to the debt will pass on to the heirs of C
S cannot collect because the credit right is personal to C
S can collect only if D and C agreed that the right to the debt will pass on the heirs of C
S cannot collect because the law prohibits the transmission of the credit right

explanation: S can collect from D although D and C did not agree that the right to the debt will pass on to the heirs of C.

text: A borrowed from B a sum of money with a stipulated rate of interest to be paid in three equal monthly installments from January to March. A paid an amount for which the latter issued a receipt stating that th e payment is for the month of February. In this case

choices.text: The installment for the month of March is also considered paid
The installment for the month of January is conclusively presumed to have been paid
The installment for the month of January is distributably presumed paid
The installment for the month of January is not presumed paid

explanation: The installment for the month of January is conclusively presumed to have been paid.

text: A obliged himself to deliver the cans of powdered milk of B from his warehouse in Pangasinan to Manila. While his truck w as traveling on the North expressway, it was hi -jacked by a band of robber who also took the cans of milk belonging to B. Is A liable for the loss of the goods?

choices.text: While his truck w as traveling on the North expressway, it was hi -jacked by a band of robber who also took the cans of milk belonging to B. Is A liable for the loss of the goods?
No, because they were generic things and as they cannot be lost
Yes, because he was in possession of the same at the time of the loss and therefore presumed at fault
Yes, because there was no stipulation exempting him from loss in case of fortuitous event

explanation: A was in possession of the cans at the time of the loss, so he is presumed at fault.

text: A obliged himself to pay B P100,000 in 30 days plus a penalty of P10,000 if A fails to pay the obligation in due time. A failed to pay the obligation in 30 days, B can demand from A

choices.text: The principal of P100,000 plus P10,000 penalty
The principal of P100,000 plus P10,000 penalty plus legal interest
The principal of P100,000 plus P10,000 penalty, plus legal interest, plus damages
The principal of P100,000 plus legal interest, plus damages

explanation: When a debtor fails to pay on time, the creditor can demand the principal amount, the penalty, legal interest, and damages.

text: D is obliged to give C a specific ring. The parties that D may give a specific bracelet as substitute. Which of the following statements is true?

choices.text: If the ring is lost through a fortuitous event before substitution, the obligation is extinguished
If the bracelet is lost through a fortuitous event before substitution, the obligation is extinguished
If the ring is lost through a fortuitous event after substitution, the obligation is extinguished
If the ring is lost through the debtors fault after substitution, the debtor shall pay damages

explanation: If the principal object (ring) is lost through a fortuitous event before substitution, the obligation is extinguished.

text: D owes C P10,000 with G as guarantor. C, on the other hand, owes D, P8,000. Both debts are already due, but D is insolvent. In this case

choices.text: C may collect from G P10,000
C may collect from G P2,000 because the guarantor can set up compensation as regards what the creditor may owe the principal debtor
C may collect nothing from G because D is insolvent
C may collect P8,000 from G

explanation: The guarantor can set up compensation for what the creditor owes the principal debtor, so C can only collect P2,000 from G.

text: D owes C P50,000. Subsequently, D proposed to C that T will assume his Ds debt. C accepted the proposal of D. Assume also that on due date, T could not pay because of his insolvency which was in fact subsisting but was not known to D or of public knowledge at the time that D delegated his debt. In this case

choices.text: C can revive Ds debt because Ts insolvency was already existing at the time that D delegated his debt
C can revive Ds debt whether or not he D was aware of Ts insolvency since he D proposed the substitution
C cannot hold D liable because his Ds obligation was extinguished when he was substituted by T
The novation is void because D did not take st eps to determine the solvency of T when he D delegated his debt

explanation: Since D proposed the substitution, C can revive D's debt regardless of whether D was aware of T's insolvency.

text: D stole the carabao of C. D was arrested, tried in court and convicted. Aside from being sentenced to a prison term, D was also ordered by the court to return the carabao. However, the carabao died before D could deliver it to C.

choices.text: Aside from being sentenced to a prison term, D was also ordered by the court to return the carabao. However, the carabao died before D could deliver it to C.
D is not liable to C if the cause of the death of the carabao is a fortuitous event
D is liable to C only if the carabao died because of Ds fault
D is liable to C whatever may be the cause of the death of the carabao

explanation: Since D was convicted of theft, he is liable for the value of the carabao regardless of how it died.

text: A, B and C are solidary debtors of X in the amount of P3,000. X renounces the share of A and A accepts the renunciation. Thereafter, B becomes insolvent

choices.text: C alone will be liable for the balance of P2,000
A will be liable for P500, while C will be liable for P1,500
C will be liable only for his share of P1,000 A will no longer be liable since his share was already renounced by X
A will be liable for P1,000, while C will be liable for P1,000, for the remaining balance of P2,000

explanation: After X renounces A's share and B becomes insolvent, A and C will each be liable for P1,000 of the remaining P2,000.

text: D owes C P30,000 due on June 20, C owes D the following debts P15,000 due on June 2 P4,000 due on June 14 P6,000 due on June 16 and P3,000 due on June 18. On June 17, C assigned his right to X. C notified D of the assignment but D did not give his consent thereto. On June 20, how much may X collect from D?

choices.text: Nothing

explanation: X can collect P5,000 from D after deducting the debts that C owes to D that are already due.

text: A, B and C are solidarily liable to X for P30,000. A is insolvent and X condoned Bs share in the obligation. Which of the following statement is correct?

choices.text: C is liable to X in the amount of P10,000 only
B is still liable to X in the amount of P20,000
X may only collect P10,000 from B
X may only collect P10,000 from C

explanation: Since A is insolvent and X condoned B's share, C is only liable for his share of P10,000.

text: A, B and C are solidary debtors of X, Y and Z, solidary creditors, in the amount of P2,700. X renounces the whole obligation without the consent of Y and Z. the debtors ac cepted the renunciation

choices.text: The whole obligation is extinguished
Only P900 is extinguished
No part of the obligation is extinguished because not all the creditors consented to the renunciation
Only P300 is extinguished

explanation: Since X is one of three solidary creditors, only his share of P900 is extinguished by the renunciation.

text: A, B and are liable jointly in the amount of P60,000 to D and E, joint creditors. D condoned the whole obligation. How much obligation is extinguished by remission?
explanation: Since D is one of two joint creditors, only his share of P30,000 is extinguished by the remission.

text: D obliged himself to give 5 grams of shabu to C. later, the parties agreed that D would instead give to C 5 sacks of rice. Which of the following statements is correct?

choices.text: The novation is void because the original obligation is void. Hence, C cannot demand the delivery of 5 sacks of rice from D
The novation is valid because the new obligation is valid. Hence, C can demand the delivery of 5 sacks of rice from D
The original obligation although void is validated by the new obligation. Hence, C can demand the delivery of 5 sacks of rice from D

The new obligation is only voidable because D had not yet performed the original obligation at the time of the novation. Accordingly, the new obligation is binding, and C may demand the delivery of 5 sacks of rice from D until the new obligation is annulled by a proper action in court

explanation: Since the original obligation to deliver shabu is void (illegal), the novation is also void and C cannot demand the delivery of rice.

text: Upon the proposal of a third person, a new debtor substituted the original debtor without the latters consent. The creditor accepted the substitution. Later, however, the new debtor became insolvent and defaulted in his obligation. What is the effect of the new debtors default upon the original debtor?

choices.text: The original debtor is freed of liability since novation took place and this relieved him of his obligation
The original debtor shall pay or perform the obligation with recourse to the new debtor
The original debtor remains liable since he gave no consent to the substitution
The original debtor shall pay or perform 50 of the obligation to avoid unjust enrichment on his part

explanation: Since the original debtor did not consent to the substitution, he remains liable for the obligation.

text: D has a grains warehouse in Davao, while C has a grains warehouse in Cebu. D borrowed 10 sacks of rice worth P10,000 from C for Ds customer in Cebu. Later, C borrowed 10 sacks of rice which was also worth P10,000 from D for Cs customer in Davao. Both the obligations are already due. Transport costs to Davao amount to P1,000, while those for Cebu amount to P800

choices.text: D and C need not pay each other since their debts compensated each other
D and C need not pay each other since their debts compensated each other, except for the delivery charges which C must pay to D in the amount of P200 P1,000 less P800
Compensation cannot take place because the debts are payable at different places
D must pay C P10,800, while C must pay D P11,000

explanation: The debts can be compensated, but C must pay D the difference in transport costs (P200).

text: A has checking account in BDO Unibank with positive balance of P1,000,000. A borrowed of P1,000,000 from the same bank. At the maturity date of the loan payable of A, what mode of extinguishing obligation is present?

choices.text: Condonation
Merger
Compensation
Delegacion

explanation: Since A has a deposit and a loan with the same bank, the obligation can be extinguished through compensation.

text: H and W are legally separated based on a court judgment. The decision requires H to give monthly support to W of P10,000 at the beginning of each month. On March 2020, W purchased goods on account from Hs business in the amount of P10,000 with maturity date on May 1, 2020. H has not given Ws monthly support for the month of April 2020 and May 2020. Which is incorrect?

choices.text: If W demands her support for the month of April, H may set up compensation as regards to the debt W owes him
If W demands her support for the month of May, H may claim compensation as regards to the debt W owes him
If H demands payment of the debt from the sale of goods, W may set up compensation as regards to her support for the month of April
If H demands payment for the debt from the sale of goods, W may set up compensation as regards to her support for the month of May

explanation: H cannot claim compensation for the May support because the debt from the sale of goods is not yet due on May 1.

text: A real contract has the following essential elements

choices.text: Consent of the contracting parties, object certain and cause of consideration
Consent of the contracting parties, object certain, cause of considera tion and delivery of the object
Consent of the contracting parties, object certain, cause of consideration and formalities required by law
Consent of the contracting parties, object certain, delivery of the object, and formalities required by law

explanation: A real contract requires consent, object, cause, and delivery of the object.

text: In the order that stipulation in favor of a third person would be valid and binding upon the parties thereto, the following are requisites, except

choices.text: There must be a stipulation in favor of a third person
That there must be an existing agency between either of the contracting parties and the third person
The contracting parties must have clearly and deliberately conferred a favor upon the third person
The third person communicated his acceptance to the obligor before its revocation

explanation: An existing agency is not a requirement for a valid stipulation in favor of a third person.

text: The defective contracts arranged according to the degree of their defectiveness from the least defective to the most defective are

choices.text: Voidable, rescissible, unenforceable, and void contracts
Rescissible, unenforceable, voidable, and void contracts
Rescissible, voidable, unenforceable, and void contracts
Unenforceable, rescissible, voidable, and void contracts

explanation: This is the correct order of defective contracts from least to most defective.

text: The following are attributes of a rescissible contract, except

choices.text: It is valid and rescinded
It is a principal remedy of the creditor to collect his credit
Damage or lesion is absolutely material
Third person whose interest is affected may ask for rescission

explanation: Rescission is not a principal remedy for collection of credit.

text: Which of the following contracts is not rescissible?

choices.text: Those which are entered into by guardians whenever the wards whom they represent suffer a lesion of more than  of the value of the object of the contract
Those where one of the parties is incapable of giving consent to a contract
Those executed in representation of an ab sentee, if the latter suffers a lesion more than  of the value of the object of the contract
Those undertaken in fraud of creditors when the latter cannot in any other manner collect the claims due to them

explanation: Contracts where one party is incapable of giving consent are voidable, not rescissible.

text: The following are attributes of a voidable contract. Which is not?

choices.text: It is binding, valid and enforceable before annulment
Damage is material to be voidable
It can be ratified and ratification has retroactive effect
The capacitated cannot allege the incapacity of the other party

explanation: Damage is not a requirement for a contract to be voidable.

text: Which of the following contracts must be both in writing and public instrument to be enforceable and valid?

choices.text: Agreement to pay interest in a contract of loan
Contract of sale of a piece of land by the agent in the name of the principal
Contract of donation of real property
Contract of Antichresis

explanation: A contract of donation of real property must be in a public instrument to be valid.

text: The following contracts are voidable, except

choices.text: Contracts entered into during a state of drunkenness or hypnotic spell
Contracts entered into during a lucid interval
Contracts where one of the parties is incapacitated to give consent
Contracts where the consent of one party is vitiated by violence, intimidation, mistake, fraud or undue influence

explanation: Contracts entered into during a lucid interval are valid, not voidable.

text: The following contracts are unenforceable, except

choices.text: Those entered into by one who has no authority or legal representation
Those that do not comply with the Statute of Frauds
Those where both parties are incapable of giving consent to a contract
Those where the consent of a party is vitiated by violence, intimidation, mistake, fraud or undue influence

explanation: Contracts where consent is vitiated by violence, intimidation, mistake, fraud or undue influence are voidable, not unenforceable.

text: The following contracts are required to appear in a public document for the convenience of the parties so that they may be registered into the proper recording office, except

choices.text: Contracts which have for their object the creation of real rights over immovable property
The acceptance of an inheritance
The power to administer property
The cession of actions or rights proceeding from an act appearing in a public document

explanation: The acceptance of an inheritance is not required to be in a public document for registration purposes.

text: When the contract lacks one of the essential elements, the contract is

choices.text: Voidable
Rescissible
Void
All of the above

explanation: A contract that lacks any of the essential elements (consent, object, and cause) is void or inexistent from the beginning.

text: If the doubts are cast upon the principal object of the contract in such a way it cannot be known what may have been the intention or will of the parties. The contract shall be

choices.text: Voidable due to lack of meeting of minds
Interpreted for there is doubt
Reformed to express the true intention of the parties
Void

explanation: When the principal object of the contract cannot be determined, there is no meeting of the minds and the contract is void.

text: It is a contract whereby the parties conceal their true agreement. Thus, the contracting parties are bound by their real agreement provided it does not prejudice a third person and is not intended for any purpose contrary to law, morals, good customs, public order or public policy

choices.text: Absolutely simulated contract
Relatively simulated contract
Vitiated contract
Ratified contract

explanation: A relatively simulated contract is one where the parties conceal their true agreement but are bound by their real agreement, provided it is not contrary to law, morals, etc.

text: An absolutely simulated contract is

choices.text: Void
Voidable
Unenforceable
Rescissible

explanation: An absolutely simulated contract is void because there is no real intention to be bound by the contract.

text: Which among the following contracts is void?

choices.text: A contract of barter between S, insane, and B, 17 years old
A contract of sale where B, the buyer, twisted the arm of S, the seller, so that S would sign the deed of sale
A contract of sale where B, the buyer, aimed a gun at the wife of S, so that S would sign the deed of sale
A contract for the sale of a cow which is suffering from a contagious disease

explanation: The contract is void because both parties are incapable of giving consent (insane person and unemancipated minor).

text: Sale is valid between spouses

choices.text: When there is an agreement of separation of property between the spouses in their marriage
When the spouses property regime is covered by conjugal partnership of gains
When the spouses property regime is covered by absolute community of property
When the spouses entered into contract of marriage before the effectivity of the Family Code

explanation: Sale between spouses is valid only when there is an agreement of separation of property between them.

text: The following contracts are void or inexistent, except

choices.text: Those whose cause, object or purpose is contrary to law, morals, good customs, public order or public policy
Those which are absolutely simulated or fictitious
Those whose cause or object did not exist at the time of the transaction
Those where one of the parties employed fraud to obtain the consent of the other

explanation: Contracts where consent is obtained through fraud are voidable, not void or inexistent.

text: The following contracts are void or inexistent, except

choices.text: Those whose object is outside the commerce of men
Those which contemplate an impossible service
Those where the intention of the parties relative to the principal object of the contract cannot be ascertained
Those where one of the parties is guilty of fraud in performing his obligation

explanation: Fraud in the performance of the obligation makes the contract voidable, not void or inexistent.

text: Which of the following contracts is void?

choices.text: Lease of a piece of land made by a minor without a written authority from his parents the owners
Oral sale of a piece of land made by the owner to an insane person
Written sale of a gold necklace made without authority from the owner
Written sale of a piece of land with oral authority from the owner

choices.text: True and True

False and True

text: Mistake in three of the following will make a contract voidable. Which one will not?

choices.text: Mistake as to the substance of the thing which is the object of the contract
Mistake as to the principal conditions which principally moved one or both parties to enter into the contract
Mistake as to the identity or qualifications of one of the parties in which identify or qualifications have been the principal cause of the contract
Simple mistake of account

text: Which one of the following constitutes fraud?

choices.text: Failure to disclose facts when there is a duty to reveal them as when parties are bounded by confidential reasons
Misrepresentation made not in bad faith
Misrepresentation by a third person and both parties were mistaken
Usual exaggeration in trade

text: If mistake, fraud or accident has prevented a meeting of the minds of the parties, the proper remedy is

choices.text: Reformation
Rescission
Annulment
Resolution

text: Which of the following is correct?

choices.text: An action to enforce judicially a natural obligation prescribes in 4 years
An action for annulment is imprescriptible
An action to declare a contract void is not subject to prescription
An action for rescission of contract prescribes in five years counted from the execution of the contract

text: Which of the following contracts may be subject to reformation of instruments?

Last will and testament whether notarized will or holographic will
Simple donation inter vivos wherein no condition is imposed
Pacto de retro sale actually intended as loan with equitable mortgage

text: Reformation of an instrument is available in the following cases, except

choices.text: When a mutual mistake of the parties causes the failure of the instrument to disclose their agreement
When one party was mistaken, and the other party acted fraudulently or inequitably in such a way that the instrument does not show their true intention
When a party was mistaken and the other knew or be lieved that the instrument did not state their real agreement

text: A offered to sell her watch to B for P1,000. B offered to buy the watch for P800, but it was rejected by A. When B turned to go away, A called him and said she is now willing to sell the watch for P800. May B refuse to buy the said watch?

choices.text: No, there is a meeting of the minds between the parties of the subject matter and the cause of the contract

Yes, because B made a counter -offer which was rejected by A

Yes, since there was already offer and acceptance

Yes, because A cannot withdraw the offer within two weeks as he is under estoppel

text: S offers to sell his house to B for P100,000. B asks him if he would accept P80,000. Which of the following is correct?

choices.text: Because of ambiguity, both offers are terminated by operation of law
Bs response is a mere inquiry, the P100,000 offer by S is still there
Bs response is a counter -offer effectively terminating the P100,000 offer and instigating an offer for P80,000
Bs response is a rejection of the P100,000 offer and there is no offer for P80,000 because it is too indefinite to be an offer

text: S offers to sell his car to B for P125,000 cash . B accepts the offer but is willing to pay only P120,000

choices.text: The contract was perfected at the price of P125,000
The contract was perfected at the price of P120,000
The contract was perfected at the price of P122,500
The contract was not perfected because the acceptance by B was qualified and it constituted a counter - offer

text: X offered to sell his house and lot to Y for P1,500,000. X told Y that he was giving Y thirty 30 days to decide whether to buy the house and lot. choices.text: Yes, X may withdraw the offer because he stands to gain an added profit of P500,000 and this will be more than enough to pay any damages to Y

No, X may not withdraw the offer because the option was accepted by Y although Y did not give anything in support thereof

text: On October 3, 2020, D requested for a loan of P10,000 from C and he offered to pledge his ring as security for the loan. Which of the following statements is correct?

choices.text: The contract of loan between them was perfected when C accepted the offer of D on October 3, 2020
Both contracts of loan and pledge were perfected only on October 6, 2020
The contract of loan was perfected when C gave the money to D on October 5, 2020
The contract of pledge was perfected when C gave the money to D on October 5, 2020

choices.text: The contract was not perfected because P, the real party to the sale, died before the acceptance came to his knowledge
The contract was perfected on March 1, 2020
The contract was perfected on March 3, 2020
The contract was perfected on March 5, 2020

explanation: The contract was not perfected because P, the real party to the sale, died before the acceptance came to his knowledge.

text: S and B signed a deed of sale of specific motor vehicle at a pri ce of P200,000. The parties agreed that S would deliver the said car and B would pay the price after two weeks. Yes because the contract of sale is not yet perfected without payment of earnest money
No because S was already bound by his contract with B and he cannot unilaterally withdraw from it
Yes because S has not yet delivered the car

text: D and C entered into a contract wherein D agreed to give to C P50,000 within 30 days from the date of the execution of their agreement, which, however, does not state the considerat ion received by D from C. What is the status of the contract between D and C?

choices.text: The contract is void because the cause is not stated in the contract
The contract is valid because the cause is presumed to exist and that it is lawful
The contract is rescissible because D suffered damage by reason of absence of cause
The contract is valid provided another contract is executed between D and C to state the cause

text: A died leaving properties estimated at P1,000,000 to his sons S and T. Subsequently, S sol d one -half of his inheritance to X for P300,000, although his share was still to be delivered.

choices.text: The contract is valid since the inheritance is an existing inheritance.
The contract is void because what S sold is future inheritance which may not be the object of a contract as a rule
The contract is rescissible

explanation: The contract is void because what S sold is future inheritance which may not be the object of a contract as a rule.

text: A was forced by B to sign a contract. C, a creditor of A, wants to annul the contract. Is C allowed by law to do so?

choices.text: No, because a third person cannot assail a contract
Yes, because the contract is voidable and C is damaged
Yes, a third person can annul a rescissible contract
No, because a third person cannot assail a voidable contract

explanation: C is allowed by law to annul the contract because the contract is voidable and C is damaged.

text: In a contract of sale executed by S and B, S sold his car to B for P500,000. It turned out however, S has three vehicles Fortuner valued at P800,000, Monterosport valued P700,000 and a Trailblazer valued at P600,000. Which of the following is correct?

choices.text: The contract shall be reformed because there was mistake
The parties can ask for interpretation because the word motor vehicle is ambiguous
There is no contract
The parties can ask for annulment of the contract

explanation: The parties can ask for interpretation because the word motor vehicle is ambiguous.

text: S owns an oil painting. Being in need o f money, S sold the painting to B for P1,000. After the sale, it was discovered that the painting was valuable and wort h P5,000

choices.text: S may rescind the contract due to lesion or inadequacy of cause
S may annul the contract because of the fraud
B is entitled to the benefit of the contract because it is valid and binding
S may annul the contract on the ground of error

explanation: S may annul the contract because of the fraud.

text: A forced B to sell him his ring. B sued for annulment, but A had already lost the ring thru fortuitous event. Is A liable for loss?

choices.text: A is not liable because the loss was without his fault
A is liable to pay damages if he cannot replace the ring
A is not liable to because no one shall be responsible for the loss of a thing due to fortuitous event
A is liable for the loss even if it was due to fortuitous event because of his bad faith

explanation: A is liable to pay damages if he cannot replace the ring.

text: A and B mutually promised to marry each other. The promise being verbal and without witnesses to the promise. A did not marry B. B is now suing A for damages. Decide.

choices.text: The contract is unenforceable hence A is not liable
The contract is unenforceable because mutual promise to marry is covered by the Statute of Frauds
A may be liable for damages because mutual promise to marry is not covered by Statute of Frauds

explanation: A is liable for damages even if the contract is unenforceable.

text: A, minor, sold to B a parcel of land registered in his name misrepresenting to the latter that he is of legal age. Having been misled as to the true age of A, B entered into the contract. Is the contract voidable?

choices.text: It is voidable because the seller is the person incapable of giving consent to the contract being a minor
It is voidable because of mistake on the part of B when he thought that A was of legal age

text: X alleged that Y promised to give him one hectare of land. This is in consideration of Xs meritorious services to Y. Y pleads in defense that since the promise was not in writing, it is unenforceable under the statute of Frauds. Decide.

choices.text: This is in consideration of Xs meritorious services to Y. Y pleads in defense that since the promise was not in writing, it is unenforceable under the statute of Frauds. Decide.

The Statute of Frauds is not applicable here, because the promise to give the land is not a sale of real property
The statute of Frauds is applicable because A has rendered services

choices.text: This prompted C to threaten to file a civil case to collect a sum of money against D. Afraid that he would be sued, D executed a contract transferring his car to C with book value of P95,000 as payment of the obligation which the latter a ccepted. Which is correct?

choices.text: Intimidated, B married As daughter against his will
The contract is not voidable because the threat was made by a third person not by one of the parties

choices.text: The contract is valid only if the inheritance valued at least equal or more than P50,000
The contract is void if nothing remains of the inheritance to be turned over to B
The contract is rescissible
Contract is void, future inheritance cannot be the object of sale

B cannot compel A to execute the deed of sale being oral is unenforceable

Yes, because the contract although rescissible is valid, binding and enforceable before rescission

A cannot recover the money because the contract is unenforceable
No recovery and both A and B will be prosecuted for their crime
A can recover the money although the contract is void since the crime was not committed

choices.text: Notwithstanding the knowledge of this fact, D paid the amount. Reali zing this mistake D wants to recover the amount he paid
D can recover on the ground of mistake
D cannot recover
D can recover because his obligation is not enforceable

A is obliged to deliver if B is ready to pay the price

A is not bound to deliver because the sale is unenforceable

S is not liable to pay because the contract of service is voidable

text: S sold B his parcel of land worth P10 million for only P5 million. After the sale and realizing his damage, S is now seeking to set aside the sale

choices.text: The sale is valid, binding and enforceable because as a rule, lesion or inadequacy of cause or price in a sale does not in validate a contract
It is rescissible because of the lesion or damage suffered by S
S has the right for an increase in the price to prevent unjust enrichment on the part of B
The contract is voidable because of mistake of the seller

text: S, 15 years old orally sold and delivered a bike to B, an insane, who paid P1,000. choices.text: The contract of sale remains to be unenforceable because the contracting parties are both in capacitated
