The contract is validated from inception because of the subsequent acts of the guardians of the contracting parties

An oral contra ct for the sale of a piece of land for P50,000 with the buyer giving a down payment of P20,000

Mortgage of a commercial lot to secure a loan of P50,000
Donation and acceptance of a residential lot

Sole proprietorship

Principal, because it can stand by itself

Created by operation of law
No power of succession

Liquidation

Consent
Delivery of contributions

choices.text: A partner has a personality separate from the partnership
A partnership must have a lawful object or purpose
A partnership may not be constituted in any form
There is no co-ownership, co-possession and agency in partnership

Managing

text: A partnership formed for the exercise of a profession which is duly registered is an example of

choices.text: Universal partnership of profits
Particular partnership
Universal partnership of all present property
Partnership by estoppel

explanation: A partnership formed for the exercise of a profession which is duly registered is an example of a particular partnership.

text: A partnership without a definite period and which can be dissolved at any time by any of the partners is called

choices.text: Particular partnership
Universal part nership of profits
Universal partnership of all present property
Partnership at will

text: A partnership which comprises all the profits that the partners may acquire by their work or industry during the existence of the partnership is called

choices.text: Universal partnership of all present property
Universal partnership of profits
Partnership at will
Particular partnership

explanation: A universal partnership of profits comprises all the profits that the partners may acquire by their work or industry during the existence of the partnership.

text: A partnership whereby the partners contribute to a common fund all the property actually belonging to them at the time of the constitution of the partnership, with the intention of dividing the same among themselves, as well as the profits which they may acquire therewith is

choices.text: Partnership at will
Universal partnership of profits
Universal partnership of all present property
Particular partnership

text: The following persons are disqualified to form a universal partnership, except

choices.text: Those guilty of adultery and concubinage
Husband and wife
Those guilty of the same criminal offense, if the partnership is entered into in consideration of the same
Brother and sister

text: Three of the following partnership contracts are void. Which one is not?

choices.text: Which one is not?
A universal partnership of all present property between husband and wife
A universal partnership of profits between a man and a woman living together as husband and wife without the benefit of marriage
A particular partnership between husband and wife

text: A partner can engage in business for himself without the consent of his co-partners if he is

choices.text: A capitalist partner
An industrial partner
A managing partner
A limited partner

explanation: An industrial partner can engage in business for himself without the consent of his co-partners, as long as it is not in competition with the partnership.

text: A partner who is not authorized to manage the partnership business

choices.text: Cannot bind the partnership
Can bind the partnership in all cases
Can bind the partnership only in cases of emergency
Can bind the partnership only with the consent of the managing partner

text: The following are rights of a partner, except

choices.text: To participate in the management
To share in the profits
To receive interest on capital
To inspect the books

text: A partner who is excluded from the management of the partnership

choices.text: Has no right to participate in the management
Has the right to participate in the management
Has the right to participate only in major decisions
Has the right to participate only in financial decisions

text: A partner who is excluded from the management of the partnership

choices.text: Has no right to inspect the books
Has the right to inspect the books
Has the right to inspect only financial records
Has the right to inspect only management records

explanation: Every partner has the right to inspect the partnership books, regardless of whether they are excluded from management.

text: In the absence of agreement as to sharing of partnership losses, how shall the losses be distributed to the partners?

choices.text: In proportion to their capital contributions
In proportion to their share in the profits
Equally
In proportion to their time and effort

explanation: In the absence of an agreement, losses shall be distributed in the same proportion as profits.

text: Which of the following is not a cause for the dissolution of a partnership?

choices.text: Expiration of the term
Accomplishment of the purpose
Death of a partner
Admission of a new partner

explanation: The admission of a new partner does not dissolve the partnership, but rather creates a new partnership.

text: A partnership is dissolved by the death of a partner

choices.text: Always
Never
Only if the partnership agreement so provides
Only if the surviving partners so agree

explanation: The death of a partner automatically dissolves the partnership, unless there is a contrary agreement.

text: Upon dissolution of a partnership, the assets shall be applied in the following order:

choices.text: Payment of partnership debts, return of capital contributions, distribution of profits
Return of capital contributions, payment of partnership debts, distribution of profits
Distribution of profits, payment of partnership debts, return of capital contributions
Payment of partnership debts, distribution of profits, return of capital contributions

Is entitled to a share in the profits
Is entitled to a share in the profits only if the other partners agree
Is entitled to a share in the profits only if the court so orders

text: A, B and C are partners in ABC Partnership. D represented himself as a partner in ABC Partnership to E, who, on the belief of such representation, extended P50,000 credit to ABC Partnership. Assuming only B and C consented to such representation, who will be held liable to E?

B, C and D are partners by estoppel and thus, are liable pro-rata to E
Partners A, B and C who benefited from the credit extended by E are liable
D, who made the representation, is liable to E

text: A and B entered into a universal partnership of profits. Subsequently, A became a professor in a university. Will A's salary belong to the partnership?

choices.text: Yes, because the salary was acquired through A's industry or work
No, unless it is stipulated that his salary shall be deemed contributed
No, because it is not considered a profit acquired from a property
Yes, if stipulated by the partners

explanation: In a universal partnership of profits, only profits from property are included unless otherwise stipulated.

text: A and B entered into a universal partnership of profits. Later, A purchased a parcel of land. Will the fruits of the said land belong to the partnership?

choices.text: Will the fruits of the said land belong to the partnership?
No, because the fruits of property shall refer only to property possessed by the partners at the time of the celebration of the contract
Yes, because the fruits are from the property of A
Yes, because the fruits under the law shall also cover after-acquired property

text: A, B, C and D are partners in ABCD Enterprises, a pet shop, with A contributing P50,000, B, P20,000 and C, P30,000. D is an industrial partner and manages the partnership. Based on the foregoing information, which of the following statement is false?

D is not liable for the losses of the partnership
D may be held liable with her separate property for partnership debts after the exhaustion of partnership assets

text: A, B and C are capitalist partners while D is an industrial partner. A, the managing partner, engaged personally in a business that is the same as the business of the partnership without the consent of the other partners. As a result,

choices.text: If there are losses, the partnership will bear the losses
If there are profits, the profits will be shared by A and the partnership
If there are profits, A will give the profits to the partnership
A will be excluded from the partnership and will pay damages

explanation: If a partner engages in a competing business without consent, any profits must be given to the partnership.

text: X, Y and Z are equal partners of XYZ Partnership. A owes the XYZ Partnership for P9,000. Z, a partner, collected P3,000 from A, before X and Y received anything. Z issued a receipt on the P3,000 as his share of what A owes. When X and Y collected from A, A was insolvent.

choices.text: Partner Z shall share the P3,000 with partners X and Y
Z cannot be required to share the P3,000 with X and Y
X and Y should first exhaust all remedies to collect from A
X and Y can automatically deduct from the capital contributions of Z in the partnership their respective share in the P3,000

explanation: Since A was insolvent, Z cannot be required to share the P3,000 with X and Y.

text: ABCDEFG Company, a partnership engaged in the buying and selling of car spare parts, has the following partnership with their respective contributions A P10,000 B P20,000 C P30,000 D P40,000 E P100,000 F P20,000 and G P30,000. choices.text: None will prevail because the voting was equal
The group of B, F and G will not prevail because they do not own the controlling interest
None will prevail because no one was appointed as manager in the partnership
The partners will have to appoint a manager in order to resolve the conflict

explanation: Since B opposed A's proposal, the group of B, F, and G will not prevail. The partners will have to appoint a manager in order to resolve the conflict.

text: A, B, C, D and E are general partners in ABCDE Partnership. E is appointed as managing partner in the Articles of Co-partnership. Which of the following statements is correct?

choices.text: E may be removed as managing partner by the vote of controlling partners but only if there is valid cause for removal
E may only be removed by the vote of all partners including the managing partner regardless of the reasons
Es decision on acts of management may be reversed by the majority vote of the partners even if E acted in good faith
Majority vote of all partners is necessary for act of administration

explanation: E may only be removed by the vote of all partners including the managing partner regardless of the reasons.

text: A, B, C, D and E are general partners in ABCDE Partnership. E is appointed as managing partner in a separate document other than the articles of co-partnership. Which of the following statements is correct?

choices.text: E may be removed as managing partner by the vote of controlling partners regardless of the reasons
Es decision on acts of management requires ratification of the majority of the partners to be valid
Es decision on acts of management may not be reversed by the majority vote of the partners if E acted in good faith
Majority vote of all partners is necessary for act of administration

explanation: Es decision on acts of management requires ratification of the majority of the partners to be valid.

text: A, B, C, D and E are general partners in ABCDE Partnership. No one is appointed as managing partner. Which is correct?

choices.text: All the partners shall be considered agents and whatever any one of them may do alone shall bind the partnership
Unanimous vote is necessary for the validity of an act of management
The vote of controlling partner shall prevail in case of dispute in act of management
Majority vote is enough for act of strict dominion

explanation: All the partners shall be considered agents and whatever any one of them may do alone shall bind the partnership.

text: A is the managing partner of ABC Partnership. X owes A personally and ABC Partnership P20,000 each. A collected and received from X, P10,000 and he issued a receipt wherein it is stated that the amount is applied against his personal credit.

choices.text: The amount received will be applied in favor of the partnership credit
The amount will be applied in proportion to both credits
The amount received will be applied in the credit of A
All the partners will decide as to whose favor it will apply

explanation: The amount received will be applied in the credit of A.

text: A, B, C and D are partners in ABCD Company with D as manager. T owes ABCD Company P5,500 and A, in As personal capacity, P4,500. Ts debt to A is secured by a pledge of her diamond ring. Both debts are already due. T pays P4,500 to A and tells her that the same is in payment of her debt to A. Thus, A issues her personal receipt. Which is correct?

choices.text: The payment of P4,500 will be applied to the partnership credit at 2,475 and to As credit at P2,025
The payment will be applied entirely to As credit
The payment will be applied as follows P5,500 to partnership and the balance to A in the amount of P1,000
T, A and ABCD Company will have to agree as to which credit the payment shall apply

explanation: The payment will be applied entirely to As credit.

text: A, B and C are partners in ABC Partnership. Later, they sold their ABC Partnership business to D with the agreement that D shall assume all the liabilities of the partnership to third persons. However, the third persons have no knowledge of the sale to D. Which is correct?

choices.text: The liabilities of ABC Partnership to third persons are extinguished
Third party creditors may only ask from D for payment of ABC partnership obligation
The creditors of ABC partnership are no longer creditors of A, B and C
A, B and C remain to be liable to the creditors of ABC Partnership in addition to Ds liability to these creditors

explanation: The liabilities of ABC Partnership to third persons are extinguished.

text: X is an accountant and Y is a lawyer. Can they form a particular partnership for an accounting practice?

choices.text: Yes, they are both professionals
No, because in the practice of profession, all partners must belong to the same profession and the partnership should be for the exercise of common profession
No, because they have different fields of interest
Yes, partnership may pertain to the particular of profession

text: Three lawyers formed a law partnership. The senior and well-known partner died. Can they still continue using the name of such deceased partner?

choices.text: Can they still continue using the name of such deceased partner?
Yes, as long as they will put some mark in the name indicating that such partner is already deceased
Yes, since he was a partner
No, as he is already excluded from the partnership

explanation: The partnership has been dissolved upon the death of the senior and well-known partner.

text: Mr. X is a partner who was able to bring in enormous profits to the partnership. With the consent of the other partners, he used the partnership car in meeting his clients. choices.text: He can ask that whatever damages he is responsible for shall be deducted from the profits and benefits which he may have earned for the partnership
He is obliged to compensate the partnership for the damages it was ordered to pay
The partnership and all the partners are solidarily liable
Mr. X is personally responsible to the partnership for the damages suffered by it through his fault

explanation: The partnership and all the partners are solidarily liable for the damages suffered by it through Mr. X's fault.

text: A and B are partners in buying and selling cars. A, by the partners agreement, was authorized to buy only in cash. One day, A bought on credit a car from X, a client, who did not know of As lack of authority. As purchase was made in the name of the partnership. Is the partnership bound in the sale?

choices.text: The partnership is not bound because the contract is unenforceable, A exceeded his authority
It is not bound because the contract with X is not in the ordinary course of business
It is bound because X was in good faith and the act of A was apparently in the conduct of the business.
It is bound if it ratifies the contract of sale by acceptance of benefits

text: A, B and C are partners in ABC Company with contributions of P10,000, P40,000 and P50,000, respectively. Their agreement shows that they will share in the profits in the ratio of 234. choices.text: Equally at P3,000 each
The partners must establish first a loss sharing agreement before the loss may be divided because they failed to have an agreement on the division of loss

text: A, B, C, D, E and F are partners in ABCDEF Enterprises, a dealer in cosmetics and other beauty products, with contributions of P60,000, P50,000, P40,000, P30,000, P20,000, and P10,000, respectively. No one was appointed as manager in the articles of partnership.

choices.text: A is the manager because she made the biggest investment
Every act in the ordinary course of the business will have to be decided by the majority determined on a per head basis
Every act in the ordinary course of the business will have to be decided by the controlling interest biggest investment although the partners owning them do not constitute the majority
All the partners are agents or managers of the partnership and any one of them may perform acts of administration

text: W, X, Y and Z organized a general partnership with W and X as industrial partners and Y and Z as capitalist partners. Y contributed P.5M and Z contributed P.2M to the common fund. choices.text: By a unanimous vote of the partners, W and X were appointed managing partners, without specification of their duties and powers. The decision of W and X shall prevail because the hiring is an act of management and as managers they can do so
That of Y and Z shall prevail because they are the capitalist partners
The decision of Y and Z because they have the controlling interest

text: ABC Limited Partnership are formed by A and B as general partners and C as limited partner. ABC Limited Partnership became bankrupt and unpaid liabilities to partnership creditors amounted to P30,000. Which is correct?

A and B are the only persons liable to the partnership creditors in the amount of P15,000 each
The partnership creditors may collect P30,000 from either A or B
The partnership creditors may collect P30,000 from either A, B or C

text: A, B, C and D are partners in AB and Company, contributing P20,000, P30,000 and P50,000 and industry, respectively. Due to financial reverses, they decided to dissolve the partnership. choices.text: Which of the following is correct if there is no profit and loss sharing agreement?
The partnership, A, B C and D will pay Y P10,000 each
Y can collect P12,500 each from partners A, B, C and D
D is exempt from loss, hence only A, B and C will bear the P90,000 loss in proportion to their capital contribution

explanation: Since D is an industrial partner, he is exempt from loss. Therefore, only A, B, and C will bear the P90,000 loss in proportion to their capital contribution.

text: A, B, C and D are partners contributing P10,000, P20,000, P30,000 and P40,000 respectively. A, B and D are the general partners while C is the limited partner. choices.text: Y collects P30,000 from the partnership and P5,000 each from partners A, B, C and D
C is exempt from loss hence, he can recover the P20,000 obligations of the partnership to him from either A, B or D
The P20,000 obligation of the partnership to C can be used to offset Cs capital deficiency
Y collects P30,000 from the partnership and the balance of P20,000 will be collected from A, B and D in equal share

text: A, B and C are partners in ABC Partnership. A is the managing partner. A, without the knowledge of B and C, used the partnership car for his personal use. While driving the car, A figured in an accident causing damage to X's car. Who is liable to X?

ABC Partnership only

A, B and C

text: A, B and C are partners in ABC Partnership. A is the managing partner. A, without the knowledge of B and C, used the partnership car for his personal use. While driving the car, A figured in an accident causing damage to X's car. Who is liable to X?

choices.text: A only
ABC Partnership only
A and ABC Partnership
A, B and C

explanation: Since A was using the partnership car, both A and the partnership are liable for the damages caused to X's car.

ABC Partnership only
A and ABC Partnership
A, B and C

ABC Partnership only
A and ABC Partnership
A, B and C

text: The following are the characteristics of a contract of sale, except

choices.text: Principal, which means that a contract of sale can stand by itself
Real, which requires the delivery of the object of the contract of sale for its perfection
Onerous, where rights are acquired in exchange for a valuable consideration
Bilateral, which means that both parties are bound reciprocally to each other

explanation: A contract of sale is not real - it is consensual, meaning it is perfected by mere consent. Delivery is not required for perfection.

text: A contract of sale is perfected

choices.text: Upon compliance with the requirements of the law as to form
Upon delivery of the object of the contract
Upon the meeting of the minds on the thing which is the object of the contract and upon the price
Upon demand

explanation: A contract of sale is perfected by mere consent, upon the meeting of the minds on the object and price.

text: Which of the following may not be the object of a contract of sale?

choices.text: Things having potential existence
Things, the acquisition of which depends upon a contingency which may or may not happen
Vain hope or expectancy
Things subject to a resolutory condition

explanation: Vain hope or expectancy cannot be the object of a contract of sale as it lacks the element of certainty.

text: Can future inheritance be the subject of contract of sale?

choices.text: No, since it will put the predecessor at the risk of harm from a tempted buyer, contrary to public policy
Yes, since the death of the decedent is certain to occur
No, since the seller owns no inheritance whi le his predecessor lives
Yes, but on the condition that the amount of inheritance can only be ascertained after the obligations of the estate have been paid

explanation: Future inheritance cannot be the subject of a contract of sale as it would be contrary to public policy and could potentially harm the predecessor.

text: Statement 1: In a contract of sale, the buyer becomes owner upon delivery of the thing sold as a rule. Non-payment of price is a resolutory condition. Statement 2: In a contract to sell, the buyer becomes owner only after he has fully paid the price. Payment of the price is a suspensive condition.

choices.text: First statement is true, second is false
First is false, second is true
Both are false
Both are true

explanation: Both statements are correct. In a contract of sale, ownership transfers upon delivery with non-payment being resolutory, while in a contract to sell, ownership only transfers after full payment.

text: It is a contract by virtue of the terms of which the parties thereto promise and obligate themselves to enter into another contract at a future time, upon the happening of certain events, or the fulfillment of certain conditions

choices.text: Contract of adhesion
Contract of option
Contract of sale
Auto-contract

explanation: A contract of option is one where parties promise to enter into another contract in the future upon certain conditions being met.

text: Three of the following refer to option money. Which is the exception?

choices.text: Given when contract of sale is perfected
Given when there is no contract of sale, but as a consideration
Given to bind the offeror in a unilateral promise to buy or sell
Given as a consideration distinct from the price

explanation: Option money is given before the contract of sale is perfected, not after. It is given as consideration to bind the offeror.

text: A sum of money paid, or a thing delivered upon the making of a contract for the sale of goods, to bind the bargain, the delivery and acceptance of which makes the final assent of both parties to the contract

choices.text: Option money
Earnest money
Reservation money
Downpayment

explanation: Earnest money is given to bind the bargain and shows the final assent of both parties to the contract.

text: One of the distinctions between option money and earnest money is that earnest money is

choices.text: The consideration paid for the purpose of holding one to his promise to buy or sell a determinate thing for a certain period of time
Not part of the purchase price
Proof of the perfection of the contract of sale
Paid before the perfection of the contract of sale

explanation: Earnest money is proof that the contract of sale has been perfected, while option money is given before perfection.

text: The price in a contract of sale is certain, except

choices.text: When the parties have fixed or agreed upon a definite amount
If the price is certain with reference to another thing certain
If the fixing of the price is left to the discretion of one of the contracting parties and the price fixed is not accepted by the other party
If the price fixed is that which the thing sold would have on a definite day or in a particular exchange or market

explanation: The price is not certain if it is left to the discretion of one party and the other party does not accept the price fixed.

text: S sold his car to B. There was no fixed date for the performance of their respective obligations. The obligation of S as vendor is

choices.text: To wait for the buyer to pay the price before he delivers
To deliver the car immediately since the sale has been perfected
To deliver the car after the buyer demands delivery
Rescind the contract since the time of performance is not fixed

explanation: When no time is fixed for performance, the vendor must deliver after the buyer demands delivery.

text: In a contract of sale, what is the operative act that transfers ownership of the thing sold from the seller to the buyer?

choices.text: Delivery whether actual or constructive
Full payment of the price
Consent of the contracting parties on the determinate thing and price certain in money
Execution of the written deed of sale

explanation: Delivery, whether actual or constructive, is the operative act that transfers ownership in a contract of sale.

text: It refers to the delivery of the thing sold from hand to hand in case of movables, or the taking of possession with respect to immovables, in the presence and with the consent of the vendor

choices.text: Actual or real delivery
Traditio constitutum possessorium
Traditio longa manu
Traditio brevi manu

explanation: Actual or real delivery is the physical transfer of the thing sold from hand to hand for movables, or taking possession for immovables.

text: When delivery takes place by mere consent or agreement of the parties as when the vendor merely points to the thing sold which shall thereafter be at the disposal of the vendee if the thing sold cannot be transferred to the possession of the vendee upon sale

choices.text: Traditio symbolica
Traditio brevi manu
Traditio longa manu
Traditio constitutum possessorium

explanation: Traditio longa manu is delivery by mere consent where the vendor points to the thing sold and it is placed at the disposal of the vendee.

text: This is a kind of symbolic delivery where the vendor remains in possession of the property sold, such as by virtue of a lease agreement with the vendee

choices.text: Traditio longa manu
Traditio brevi manu
Traditio constitutum possessorium
Delivery to common carrier

explanation: Traditio constitutum possessorium is a symbolic delivery where the vendor remains in possession of the property sold, typically through a lease agreement.

text: Effected when the object of sale is already in the possession of the vendee at the time of sale so that delivery need no longer be made is

choices.text: Traditio longa manu
Traditio brevi manu
Traditio constitutum possessorium
Traditio symbolica

explanation: Traditio brevi manu occurs when the vendee already has possession of the object at the time of sale, making physical delivery unnecessary.

text: When goods are delivered to the buyer on sale or return, the ownership passes to the buyer

choices.text: Upon delivery of the goods
Upon acceptance of the buyer of the seller's offer
Upon the expiration of the period agreed upon
Upon perfection of the sale

explanation: In a sale or return transaction, ownership passes to the buyer when they accept the seller's offer.

text: One of the following statements on the transfer of ownership of the thing in sale on trial is incorrect. Which is it?

choices.text: Ownership of the thing is transferred to the vendee when he signifies his approval or acceptance to the vendor
Ownership of the thing is transferred to the vendee when he does an act adopting the transaction

Ownership of the thing is transferred to the vendee if the time fixed for the return of the thing has expired and the vendee retains the thing without giving notice of rejection or acceptance to the vendor
Ownership of the thing is transferred to the vendee upon delivery

explanation: In a sale on trial, ownership is not transferred upon delivery but rather upon the vendee's acceptance or adoption of the transaction.

text: The buyer has a right to the fruits of the things

choices.text: From the time the fruits have been delivered
From the time of perfection of the sale
From the time the obligation to deliver the thing bought arises
From the time the thing bought is delivered

explanation: The buyer's right to the fruits begins from the time the obligation to deliver arises, not from delivery or perfection.

text: The unpaid seller, in addition to his right to retain the goods while he is in possession of them, has the following rights, except

choices.text: The right of stoppage in transit
The right to resell the goods
The right to rescind the sale
The right to bid when the goods are resold

explanation: The unpaid seller does not have the right to bid when the goods are resold, as this could create a conflict of interest.

text: Three of the following are the requisites in order that an unpaid seller may exercise his right of stoppage of transitu. Which one is not?

choices.text: The seller is unpaid
The seller has not parted with the possession of the goods
The goods are in transit
The buyer is or becomes insolvent

explanation: The seller must have parted with possession of the goods for the right of stoppage in transit to apply.

text: Goods are still in transit

choices.text: If the buyer or his agent obtains delivery of the goods before their arrival at the appointed destination
When the carrier acknowledges possession of the goods as bailee for the buyer after the arrival of the goods at the place of destination
If the carrier or other bailee wrongfully refuses to deliver the goods to the buyer or his agent
If the goods are rejected by the buyer, and the carrier or other bailee continues in possession of them, even if the seller has refused to receive them back

explanation: Goods remain in transit if they are rejected by the buyer and the carrier retains possession, regardless of the seller's actions.

text: An unpaid seller loses his lien on the goods in the following cases, except

choices.text: When he delivers the goods to a carrier or other bailee for the purpose of transmission to the buyer without reserving the right of ownership in the goods
When the buyer or his agent lawfully obtains possession of the goods
When the seller waives his possessory lien
When he has obtained judgment for the price of the goods

explanation: Obtaining a judgment for the price does not cause the seller to lose his lien on the goods.

text: An unpaid seller's right to resell the goods is available in the following cases, except

choices.text: If the goods are of a perishable nature
When the seller reserved the right to resell the goods
When the buyer has defaulted in the payment of the price for an unreasonable time
When the seller has lost his lien on the goods

explanation: The seller's right to resell is not available when he has lost his lien on the goods, as he no longer has possession or control over them.

text: The justified refusal of the buyer to accept the goods produces the following effects, except

choices.text: Buyer has no duty to return the goods, unless otherwise stipulated
Title to the goods does not pass on to him
Buyer shall not be obliged to pay the price
Buyer is obliged to constitute himself as depositary until he returns the goods

explanation: The buyer is not obliged to pay the price if he refuses to accept the goods.

text: The Recto Law applies to which of the following examples of sale?

choices.text: Sale of a car on straight term
Sale of house and lot on installment
Sale of car on installment where the buyer constituted a mortgage on his truck
Sale of a piano on installments where the buyer constituted a chattel mortgage on the piano

explanation: The Recto Law applies to sales of real property, which includes house and lot on installment.

text: In a contract of sale of personal property the price of which is payable in installments, the vendo r may exercise any of the following remedies, except

choices.text: Exact fulfillment of the obligation, should the vendee fail to pay any number of installments
Cancel the sale, should the vendees failure to pay cover two or more installments
Foreclose the chattel mortgage on the property if the vendees failure to pay cover two or more installments and recover any deficiency after the foreclosure sale if they stipulated it
Foreclose the chattel mortgage on the property if the vendees failure to pay cover t wo or more installments but he may no longer recover any deficiency after the foreclosure sale

explanation: The seller may not recover any deficiency after foreclosure if the buyer has paid at least two years of installments.

text: Where the seller of goods has a voidable title thereto, but his title has not been avoided at the time of sale, the buyer acquires title to the goods. Such acquisition of title has the following requisites, except

choices.text: The buyer must have bought the goods in good faith
The buyer must have bou ght them for value
The buyer bought them without notice of the sellers defect of title
The party from whom the seller obtained the goods must ratify the sale

explanation: The seller must ratify the sale for the buyer to acquire title to the goods.

text: If a movable property is sold separately to two or more different vendees, ownership shall belon g to the person

choices.text: Who in good faith first paid the purchase price in full
Who in good faith first recorded the sale in the Registry of Property
Who in good faith presents the oldest title
Who in good faith first took possession of the property

explanation: The person who paid the purchase price in full is the owner of the property.

text: If an immovable property is sold to different vendees, the ownership shall be transferred to the person

choices.text: Who has first taken possession in good faith
Who presents the oldest title in good faith
Who in good faith first recorded it in the Registry of Property
Who has paid in good faith the purchase price in full

explanation: The person who paid the purchase price in full is the owner of the property.

text: Statement I: In waiver there is no warranty against eviction, but the seller is still liable to pay the value of the thing at the time of eviction if eviction takes place Statement II: In case of total eviction, the vendee cannot rescind the sale with damages

choices.text: Both statements are correct
Both are incorrect
First is correct, second is incorrect
First is incorrect, second is correct

explanation: Both statements are correct. In waiver there is no warranty against eviction but the seller remains liable for the value at eviction, and in case of total eviction the vendee cannot rescind with damages.

text: Statement 1: Warranty against eviction, as well as against hidden defect, may be waived by the vendee provided the vendor is in good faith Statement 2: Waiver intencionada on the part of the vendee will absolutely exempt the vendor from liability

choices.text: Both statements are false
Both are true
First is false, second is true
First is true, second is false

explanation: Both statements are correct. The vendor may waive warranty against eviction and hidden defect if in good faith, and waiver intencionada will absolutely exempt the vendor from liability.

text: Three of the following are remedies of the buyer in case of the breach of warranty by the seller. Which is not included?

choices.text: Accept or keep the goods and set up the breach of warranty by way of recoupment or extinction of the price
Rescind the contract of sale and refuse to accept the thing, or if already delivered, refuse to return the same
Accept or keep the goods and claim damages for the breach of warranty
Refuse to accept the goods and claim damages for the breach of warranty

explanation: Refusing to accept the goods and claiming damages for the breach of warranty is not a remedy but a consequence of the breach.

text: What is the prescriptive period for filing an action for breach of warranty of thing sold with hidden defect?

choices.text: 6 months from the date of delivery of the thing sold
40 days from the date of delivery of the thing sold
1 year from the date of delivery of the thing sold
3 days from the date of delivery of the thing sold

explanation: The prescriptive period for filing an action for breach of warranty of thing sold with hidden defect is 1 year from the date of delivery.

text: Action by the vendee against the vendor to nullify the sale due to some vices or defects which render the object of sale unfit for the use intended or knowledge of which, the vendee would not have bought the thing

choices.text: Accion quanti minoris
Accion reinvidicatoria
Accion pauliana
Redhibitory action

explanation: Redhibitory action is the action by the vendee against the vendor to nullify the sale due to some vices or defects which render the object of sale unfit for the use intended or knowledge of which, the vendee would not have bought the thing.

text: Three of the following are the requisites in order that the buyer may enforce the seller's liability for hidden defects. Which one is not?

choices.text: The defects of the thing sold must not be patent or visible

The defects render the thing unfit for the use for which it is intended, or which diminish its fitness for such use to such an extent that had the buyer been aware thereof, he would not have bought it
The defects must be existing at the time of sale
The defects must be capable of determination by an expert

explanation: The defects must be existing at the time of sale, diminish the fitness for use, and be capable of determination by an expert.

text: The redhibitory action based on the faults or defects of animals must be brought within

choices.text: 30 days from delivery to the vendee
40 days from delivery to the vendee
45 days from delivery to the vendee
6 months from delivery to the vendee

explanation: The redhibitory action based on the faults or defects of animals must be brought within 45 days from delivery to the vendee.

text: The vendor shall be liable for the death of the animal sold when the following requisites are present, except

choices.text: The disease existed at the time of sale
The disease must be redhibitory
The disease is the cause of the death of the animal
The animal dies within 3 days from the time of purchase

explanation: The vendor shall be liable for the death of the animal sold when the disease existed at the time of sale.

text: Action to seek a corresponding reduction in price by reason of some vices or defects in the thing purchased

choices.text: Accion quanti minoris
Accion reinvidicatoria
Accion pauliana
Redhibitory action

explanation: Redhibitory action is the action to seek a corresponding reduction in price by reason of some vices or defects in the thing purchased.

text: In three of the following cases, the buyer is not entitled to suspend the payment of the price. Which one will give him the right to suspend payment?

choices.text: Disturbance in the possession or ownership of the thing purchased
The seller gives him security for the return of the price
It has been stipulated that the buyer shall pay the price notwithstanding any disturbance
The disturbance is a mere act of trespass

explanation: The buyer is entitled to suspend the payment of the price if it has been stipulated that the buyer shall pay the price notwithstanding any disturbance.

text: A contract of sale with a right to repurchase and other contracts including a contract purporting to be an absolute sale shall be presumed to be an equitable mortgage in the following cases, except

choices.text: When the price of sale with right to repurchase is unusually inadequate
When the vendor remains in possession of the thing sold
When the period to repurchase the property is extended
When the vendee binds himself to pay the taxes due

explanation: An equitable mortgage is presumed when the price of sale with right to repurchase is unusually inadequate.

text: A contract of sale whereby the seller acquires the right to redeem or repurchase the object of the sale from the buyer within a certain period agreed upon

choices.text: Equitable mortgage
Absolute sale
On sale or return
Pacto de retro sale

explanation: An equitable mortgage is a contract whereby the seller acquires the right to redeem or repurchase the object of the sale from the buyer within a certain period agreed upon.

text: It refers to the right which the vendor reserves to himself to repurchase the thing sold, with the obligation to reimburse the vendee of the price, the expenses of the contract, any other legitimate payments made therefore and the necessary and useful expenses made on the thing sold

choices.text: Conventional redemption
Legal redemption
Equity of redemption
Right of pre-emption

explanation: Equity of redemption refers to the right which the vendor reserves to himself to repurchase the thing sold, with the obligation to reimburse the vendee of the price, the expenses of the contract, any other legitimate payments made therefore and the necessary and useful expenses made on the thing sold.

text: S sold a specific land to B under a pacto de retro sale agreement without any stipulation as to the period for the exercise of the right of redemption. What is the period available to S to exercise the right of redemption?

choices.text: 4 years
5 years
6 years
10 years

explanation: The period available to S to exercise the right of redemption is 5 years.

text: A kind of mortgage which, although lacking some formality, form of words, or requisites prescribed by law, shows the intention of the parties to charge real property as security for debt and contains nothing impossible or contrary to law is known as

choices.text: Legal mortgage
Equitable mortgage
Conventional mortgage
Voluntary mortgage

explanation: A voluntary mortgage is a kind of mortgage which shows the intention of the parties to charge real property as security for debt and contains nothing impossible or contrary to law.

text: It refers to the repurchase made by a co-owner, adjoining rural lot owner or adjoining urban lot owner of a land sold by a co-owner, adjoining rural lot owner or adjoining urban lot owner as expressly authorized by law

choices.text: Legal redemption
Legal pre-emption
Conventional redemption
Voluntary redemption

explanation: Legal redemption refers to the repurchase made by a co-owner, adjoining rural lot owner or adjoining urban lot owner of a land sold by a co-owner, adjoining rural lot owner or adjoining urban lot owner as expressly authorized by law.

text: An owner of a rural land has the right of legal redemption of an adjoining rural land sold if the following requisites are present, except when

choices.text: The adjoining rural land is not separated by any apparent servitudes for the benefit of other estates
The land sold does not exceed one hectare
The grantee owns another rural land
The grantee owns an urban land

explanation: An owner of a rural land has the right of legal redemption of an adjoining rural land sold if the grantee owns an urban land.

text: This refers to the right of an adjoining owner of an urban land to be given preference to the purchase of a small piece of urban land which is held for speculation before it is offered for sale to others

choices.text: Right of subrogation
Right of redemption
Right of pre-emption
Right of repurchase

explanation: Right of pre-emption refers to the right of an adjoining owner of an urban land to be given preference to the purchase of a small piece of urban land which is held for speculation before it is offered for sale to others.

text: A and B are co-owners of a 1,000 sq. meters urban lot. A sold his 500 sq. meters share to X. B sold his 500 sq. meters share to Y. C, an adjoining owner, wants to redeem the 1,000 sq. meters sold by A and B. Which of the following statements is correct?

choices.text: C can redeem the whole 1,000 sq. meters
C can redeem only 500 sq. meters
C cannot redeem any portion of the land
C can redeem only if X and Y do not own any urban land

explanation: C cannot redeem any portion of the land because the right of legal redemption does not apply to urban lands.

text: The following elements are common in both pledge and mortgage, except

choices.text: The contract is constituted to secure the fulfillment of a principal obligation
The property on which the security is constituted must be delivered to the creditor
The debtor must be the absolute owner of the property pledger or mortgaged
The debtor must have free disposal of the property pledged or mortgaged

explanation: In a mortgage, the property does not need to be delivered to the creditor, while in a pledge, delivery is required.

text: Which of the following statements is true?

choices.text: Pledge and mortgage are accessory contracts because they cannot exist by themselves
In both pledge and mortgage, the creditor is entitled to deficiency judgment

Where an obligation is secured by a pledge or mortgage and it is not paid when due, the pledge or mortgagee may dispose of the thing pledged or mortgaged if there is an agreement to that effect between the parties
Unless otherwise agreed upon by the parties, the sale of the mortgage property extinguishes in full the obligation of the mortgagor to the mortgagee

explanation: Pledge and mortgage are accessory contracts that depend on a principal obligation for their existence.

text: Which of the following is a similarity of chattel mortgage and pledge?

choices.text: Deficiency is recoverable in case of sale of the thing pledged/mortgaged
The object of the contract is a movable property
The excess of the proceeds of sale over the amount of the obligation belongs to the pledgor/mortgagor
An affidavit of good faith is required to bind third persons

explanation: Both chattel mortgage and pledge involve movable property as their object.

text: Which of the following stipulations in a contract of pledge is valid?

choices.text: A stipulation which provides that the contract of pledge is not extinguished by the return of the thing pledged
A stipulation allowing the appropriation by the pledgee of the thing pledged in case the same is not sold in the first and second auctions
A stipulation for the recovery of deficiency in case the proceeds from the sale of the thing pledged is less than the amount of the obligation
A stipulation authorizing the pledgee to become the automatic owner of the thing pledged in case of default by the debtor in the payment of the secured contract of loan

explanation: This is a valid stipulation as it allows the parties to agree that the pledge continues despite return of the thing pledged.

text: Which of the following statements regarding the sale of the thing pledged in public auction regarding contract of pledge is incorrect?

choices.text: The pledgee is generally entitled to the excess unless there is stipulation to the contrary
The pledgor may recover the excess if there is stipulation to that effect
The pledgee can never recover any deficiency even if there is stipulation for such recovery
The pledgor may become liable to any deficiency if there is stipulation to that effect

explanation: The pledgee can recover deficiency if there is a valid stipulation to that effect.

text: A third person who pledges his property to secure another person's debt is released from liability in the following cases, except

choices.text: When the creditor voluntarily accepts an immovable property in payment of debt
When the creditor voluntarily accepts a movable property in payment of the debt
If an extension of time is granted to the debtor by the creditor with the pledgor's consent
If through some acts of the creditor, the pledgee cannot be subrogated to the rights, mortgages and preferences of the creditor

explanation: An extension of time granted with the pledgor's consent does not release the third person from liability.

text: The debtorpledgor has the following rights, except

choices.text: To ask for the return of the thing pledged after he has paid the debt, its interests, and with expenses in a proper case
To continue to be the owner of the thing pledged unless it is expropriated
To require the deposit of the thing with a third person if it is in a danger of being impaired or lost through the negligence or willfu l act of the pledgee
To alienate the thing pledged without the consent of the pledgee

explanation: The debtor is not allowed to alienate the thing pledged without the consent of the pledgee.

text: The creditorpledgee has the following rights, except

choices.text: To retain the thing in his possession until the debt is paid
To use the thing pledged without authority if such use is necessary for its preservation
To demand reimbursement of the expenses made for the preservation of the thing
To automatically appropriate the thing pledged upon the default of the debtor in the payment of his debt

explanation: The creditor cannot use the thing pledged without authority unless it is necessary for its preservation.

text: Three of the following are essential requisites of a contract of mortgage. Which one is not?

choices.text: The person instituting the mortgage has the free disposal of his property
The contract must be in writing
The mortgagor is the absolute owner of the thing mortgaged
The mortgage is constituted to secure the fulfillment of a principal obligation

explanation: The mortgagor does not need to be the absolute owner - he only needs to have free disposal of the property.

text: One of the following may not be the object of a real mortgage

choices.text: Land, buildings, roads and construction of all kinds adhered to the soil
Fertilizer actually used on a piece of land
Animal houses, pigeon houses or other breeding places intended by the owner to be permanently attached to the land, including the animals therein
Growing fruits that have been gathered from trees planted on land

explanation: Growing fruits that have been gathered are no longer immovable property and cannot be the object of a real mortgage.

text: The following is required in order that a real mortgage will bind third persons

choices.text: The real mortgage must be accompanied by an affidavit of good faith and recorded with the Register of Deeds
The real mortgage must be in a public instrument showing a description of the thing mortgaged and the date of the real mortgage
It is sufficient that the real mortgage be in writing, public or private
The real mortgage must be recorded in the Registry of Property

explanation: To bind third persons, a real mortgage must be recorded in the Registry of Property.

text: Which of the following stipulation in a contract of real estate mortgage is valid?

choices.text: A stipulation forbidding the mortgagor-owner from alienating the immovable mortgaged
A stipulation providing that the mortgagee shall become the automatic owner of the property mortgaged upon failure of the debtor to pay the principal obligation
Upset price which refers to price set by the parties as to the amount at which the property will be sold at public auction
A stipulation prohibiting a second mortgage with respect to property registered under the Torrens System

explanation: An upset price stipulation is valid as it sets a minimum price for the auction sale.

text: Which of the following statements regarding the sale of the thing mortgaged in public auction regarding contract of real estate mortgage is correct?

choices.text: The mortgagor is generally entitled to the excess unless there is stipulation to the contrary
The mortgagee may generally recover the deficiency unless there is stipulation to the contrary
Both A and B
Neither A nor B

explanation: Both statements are correct - the mortgagor gets the excess and the mortgagee can recover deficiency unless stipulated otherwise.

text: It is a type of foreclosure of real estate mortgage which is available to the mortgage only if the deed of real estate mortgage contains a special power of attorney (SPA) authorizing the public auction of the mortgaged real property despite the absence of prior civil action

choices.text: Legal foreclosure
Judicial foreclosure
Extrajudicial foreclosure
Conventional foreclosure

explanation: Extrajudicial foreclosure requires a special power of attorney in the mortgage deed authorizing public auction without prior court action.

text: What is the period for the exercise of right of redemption in case the mortgagee is a bank while the mortgagor is a juridical person?

choices.text: Within three months from the foreclosure sale
Within 1 year from the foreclosure sale
Within a period not less than 90 days but not more than 120 days from the foreclosure sale
Within 30 days from the foreclosure sale

explanation: For bank mortgagees and juridical mortgagors, the redemption period is 90-120 days from foreclosure sale.

text: The following are the characteristics of a chattel mortgage, except

choices.text: The mortgagor must be the absolute owner of the property mortgaged
It is an accessory contract
It involves movable or immovable property
The deed of chattel mortgage must be accompanied by an affidavit of good faith to be binding against third persons

explanation: A chattel mortgage only involves movable property, not immovable property.

text: Which of the following is not a requisite of a chattel mortgage?

choices.text: The mortgagor must be the absolute owner of the property mortgaged
The contract must be in writing
The mortgage must be recorded in the Chattel Mortgage Register
The mortgage must be accompanied by an affidavit of good faith

explanation: The mortgagor need not be the absolute owner - he only needs to have free disposal of the property.

text: Which of the following statements regarding chattel mortgage is correct?

choices.text: The mortgagor can sell the property mortgaged without the consent of the mortgagee
The mortgagee can appropriate the property mortgaged in case of default
The mortgagee can foreclose the mortgage extrajudicially
The mortgagor can redeem the property after the foreclosure sale within one year

explanation: A chattel mortgage can be foreclosed extrajudicially if there is a stipulation to that effect.

text: Which of the following is not a valid stipulation in a chattel mortgage?

choices.text: A stipulation authorizing the mortgagee to extrajudicially foreclose the mortgage
A stipulation providing for the payment of attorney's fees
A stipulation that the mortgagee shall become the owner of the property upon default
A stipulation that the mortgagor shall pay the expenses of registration

explanation: This would be a pactum commissorium which is void as it allows automatic appropriation upon default.

text: Recording in the Registry of Property in the appropriate book is required for the validity of the contract of

choices.text: Pledge
Real estate mortgage
Chattel mortgage
Antichresis

explanation: A real estate mortgage must be recorded in the Registry of Property to be valid and binding against third persons.

text: Where shall contract of chattel mortgage involving shares of stocks be registered?

choices.text: Chattel Mortgage Registry where the mortgagor resides
Chattel Mortgage Registry where the principal office of the corporation is located
Both A and B
Neither A nor B

explanation: Shares of stocks are considered movable property, and the mortgagor should register the mortgage in the Chattel Mortgage Registry where the principal office of the corporation is located.

text: Which of the following statements regarding the sale of the thing mortgaged in public auction regarding contract of chattel mortgage is correct?

choices.text: The mortgagor is generally entitled to the excess unless there is stipulation to the contrary
The mortgagee may generally recover the deficiency unless there is stipulation to the contrary
Both A and B
Neither A nor B

explanation: Both statements are correct - the mortgagor gets the excess and the mortgagee can recover deficiency unless stipulated otherwise.

text: In real estate mortgage, the following rules are valid, except one

choices.text: A stipulation in the mortgage contract prohibiting the owner from alienating the property is valid
The mortgage may alienate the mortgage credit or assign to a third person in whole or in part
Any stipulation allowing the mortgage creditor to appropriate the property mortgaged is null and void
If alienation of the mortgage credit is not registered, it is still valid between the parties

explanation: Any stipulation allowing the mortgage creditor to appropriate the property mortgaged is null and void.

text: A borrowed P30,000 from B and as security, he pledged his ring, pair of earrings and necklace. On due date, A paid P20,000. As a result

choices.text: A can demand the return of one 1 of the thing pledged
A can demand the return of any two 2 of the things pledged
A can demand the return of the ring
A cannot demand the return of any of the things pledged

explanation: A paid P20,000 out of the P30,000, so he can demand the return of the ring.

text: D borrowed P30,000 from C. To secure the debt, D pledged his ring, wristwatch, and necklace. Before the debt could be paid, C died leaving X, Y and Z as heirs. By agreement among the heirs who inherited the credit, the ring would secure the share of X on the credit, the wristwatch the share of Y, and the necklace the share of Z. Later, D pays X P10,000

choices.text: D can demand the extinguishment of the pledge of the ring
X may release the pledge of the ring
The pledge of the ring will remain until the shares of Y and Z are paid by D
D can demand the extinguishment of the pledge of the ring, wristwatch and necklace because there has been partial payment

explanation: The heirs agreed to release the pledge of the ring.

text: On March 1, 2020, D obtained a loan of P10,000 from C. To secure the debt, which is payable on May 1, 2020, D pledged a promissory note amounting to P12,000 which was executed in his favor by M. The promissory note is due April 25, 2020 and properly endorsed by D to C

choices.text: On April 25, 2020, C can collect the note of P12,000 from M. The entire proceeds will belong to C
On April 25, 2020, C can collect the note of P12,000 from M. However, he must give P2,000 to D
C cannot collect from M. D is the one entitled to collect the note from M
C cannot collect from M. He must sell the note at public auction at maturity if D cannot pay

explanation: D is the one entitled to collect the note from M as the promissory note was executed in his favor.

text: D borrowed P20,000 from C. To secure the obligation, D pledged his ring to C. Before the due date, C executed a public instrument stating that he was abandoning the pledge and informed D about it. In the meantime, the ring remained in the possession of C

choices.text: D must accept the renunciation in order to extinguish the pledge
C must return the ring to D to extinguish the pledge
Ds loan obligation is extinguished by reason of the abandonment of the pledge
The pledge of the ring is extinguished although D does not accept the renunciation or has not yet received the ring from C

explanation: The pledge of the ring is extinguished although D does not accept the renunciation or has not yet received the ring from C.

text: A pledged her ring to F to secure a P10,000 obligation payable in two years. One year thereafter, F gives note in writing to A stating that the debt needs to be secured and that A may get the ring back at her most convenient time. As a result

choices.text: The principal obligation and the contract of pledge are both extinguished
Only the principal obligation is extinguished but not the contract of pledge because A did not get back the ring
Both the principal obligations and the contract of pledge are not extinguished because A did not get back the ring
The pledge is extinguished and F is constituted as a depository

explanation: Only the principal obligation is extinguished but not the contract of pledge because A did not get back the ring.

text: B borrowed P2,000 from L as evidenced by a promissory note . In order to secure the payment of the obligation, B pledged and delivered his laptop to L as collateral. At the maturity date of the secured loan, L voluntarily returned the promissory note to B. Which is correct?

choices.text: Only the contract of loan is extinguished
Only the contract of pledge is extinguished
Both contract of loan and contract of pledge are extinguished
Neither contract of loan nor contract of pledge is extinguished

explanation: Both contracts of loan and pledge are extinguished because L returned the promissory note.

text: D borrowed P100,000 from C. To secure the debt, D mortgaged his land and building in favor of C. The mortgage is registered with the Register of Deeds. Sometime, D sold the land to X who was not aware of the mortgage of the land and building. Based on the above information, which of the following statements is false?

choices.text: X must respect the mortgage although he was not a party thereto
X was not bound by the mortgage because he was not aware of it
If C foreclose the mortgage and the proceeds of the foreclosure sale are not enough to pay for the debt, C can recover the deficiency from D
If C foreclose the mortgage and the proceeds of the foreclosure sale exceed the amount of debt, D is entitled to the excess

explanation: X was not bound by the mortgage because he was not aware of it.

text: ABC Corporation obtained a loan amounting to P1,000,000 from XYZ Bank. To secure the obligation, P, the president of ABC Corporation, mortgaged his own building in favor of the bank. The contract of loan and deed of mortgage have been signed by the parties but have not been acknowledged before a notary public

choices.text: ABC Corporation and P are one and the same person
P may validly mortgage his own property to secure the obligation of ABC Corporation to the bank
The mortgage is not yet binding between the parties since it has not been notarized
The mortgage contract can stand independently form the contract of loan

explanation: P may validly mortgage his own property to secure the obligation of ABC Corporation to the bank.

text: D obtained an interest-bearing loan from XYZ Bank amounting to P100,000. To secure the obligation, D mortgaged his building to XYZ Bank. As added requirement of the loan, a fire insurance on the building was also obtained by D with XYZ Bank as beneficiary. Before the due date of the loan, the building was razed by fire

choices.text: The loan of D amounting to P100,000 is extinguished but the security remains
Only the security for the obligation is extinguished
The proceeds of the insurance policy will be the new security of the loan obligation which will subsist
Both the loan and the mortgage security are extinguished

explanation: Only the security for the obligation is extinguished because the building was razed by fire.

text: X constituted a chattel mortgage on a car valued at P1M to secure a P500,000 loan. For the mortgage to be valid, X should have

choices.text: The right to mortgage the car to the extent of half of its value
Ownership of the car
Unqualified free disposal of his car
Registered the car in his name

explanation: For the mortgage to be valid, X should have registered the car in his name.

text: It is an artificial being created by operation of law, having the right of succession and the powers, attributes and properties expressly authorized by law or incident to its existence

choices.text: Corporation
Cooperative
Partnership
Joint Venture

explanation: A corporation is an artificial being created by operation of law, having the right of succession and the powers, attributes and properties expressly authorized by law or incident to its existence.

text: Corporations are distinguished from partnerships in that

choices.text: The liability extends up to private properties
Created by agreement
No dissolution in case of death, withdrawal or resignation of the owner
Interest or ownership is transferable only if the owners consent

explanation: Corporations are distinguished from partnerships in that there is no dissolution in case of death, withdrawal or resignation of the owner due to its separate juridical personality.

text: The following are the advantages of forming a corporation, except

choices.text: There is ease in transferability of shares of stocks
It has a legal capacity to act and contract as a distinct unit in its own name
The stockholders limited liability on the obligation of the corporation
All of the above are advantages

explanation: All of the options listed are actually advantages of forming a corporation: ease of transferability of shares, legal capacity to act as a distinct unit, and limited liability of stockholders.

text: The following are the disadvantages of forming a corporation, except

choices.text: Its credit is weakened by the limited liability feature
There is high cost of formation and operations
It is subject to higher taxes or sometimes indirect double taxation
All of the above are disadvantages

explanation: All of the options listed are actually disadvantages of forming a corporation: weakened credit due to limited liability, high formation and operational costs, and potential double taxation.

text: Statement 1: A stock corporation is a corporation which has capital stock divided into shares of stocks and are authorized to distribute to the holders of such shares dividends or allotments of the surplus profits on the basis of the shares held. Statement 2: A non-stock corporation is a corporation where no part of its income is distributable as dividends to its members and the capital of the corporation is not divided into shares of stocks.

choices.text: Both statements are true
Only Statement 1 is true
Only Statement 2 is true
Both statements are false

explanation: Both statements correctly define stock and non-stock corporations. A stock corporation has capital stock divided into shares and can distribute dividends, while a non-stock corporation cannot distribute dividends and has no capital stock divided into shares.

text: It refers to a corporation with a single stockholder

choices.text: One person corporation OPC
Partnership
Joint Venture
Corporation Aggregate

explanation: A One Person Corporation (OPC) is a corporation with a single stockholder, which is a special type of corporation allowed under the Revised Corporation Code.

text: Statement 1: A civil corporation is a corporation established for business or profit Statement 2: An eleemosynary corporation is a corporation established for charitable purposes

choices.text: Both statements are true
Only Statement 1 is true
Only Statement 2 is true
Both statements are false

explanation: Both statements correctly define the types of corporations. A civil corporation is established for business or profit, while an eleemosynary corporation is established for charitable purposes.

text: Statement 1: A corporation sole is a religious corporation which consists of one member only or his successors Statement 2: A lay corporation is a corporation organized for a purpose other than for religious

choices.text: Both statements are true
Only Statement 1 is true
Only Statement 2 is true
Both statements are false

explanation: Both statements correctly define the types of corporations. A corporation sole is a religious corporation with one member and his successors, while a lay corporation is organized for non-religious purposes.

text: Statement 1: A domestic corporation is a corporation organized under the laws of the Philippines Statement 2: A foreign corporation is a corporation organized under laws other than those of the Philippines and whose laws allow Filipino citizens and corporations to do business in its own country or State

choices.text: Both statements are true
Only Statement 1 is true
Only Statement 2 is true
Both statements are false

explanation: Both statements correctly define domestic and foreign corporations. A domestic corporation is organized under Philippine laws, while a foreign corporation is organized under foreign laws and must allow Filipino citizens and corporations to do business in its country.

text: Which of the following types of corporations is not required to file articles of incorporation to obtain juridical personality as a private corporation?

choices.text: Corporation by prescription
De facto corporation
Ostensible corporation
De jure corporation

explanation: A corporation by prescription is not required to file articles of incorporation to obtain juridical personality as a private corporation. This is because it acquires its corporate existence through long and continued use of corporate powers.

text: Statement 1 Incorporators refer to the persons mentioned in the Articles of Incorporation as originally forming and composing the corporation, having signed the Articles and acknowledged the same before notary public Statement 2 Corporators in a stock corporation are called stockholders

choices.text: Both statements are true
Only Statement 1 is true
Only Statement 2 is true
Both statements are false

explanation: Both statements are correct. Incorporators are the original persons who form the corporation and sign the Articles of Incorporation, while corporators in a stock corporation are specifically called stockholders.

text: Statement 1: Corporation by estoppel or ostensible corporation refers to all persons who assume to act as a corporation knowing it to be without authority. It has no juridical personality. It has no corporate existence and is not considered an artificial being in contemplation of Revised Corporation Code Statement 2: The status of contract entered into between an ostensible corporation/corporation by estoppel and another person is valid and binding by reason of estoppel on both parties

choices.text: Both statements are true
Only Statement 1 is true
Only Statement 2 is true
Both statements are false

explanation: Both statements are correct. A corporation by estoppel has no juridical personality but contracts entered into by it are valid and binding by reason of estoppel to protect those who deal with it in good faith.

text: Statement 1: A de jure corporation refers to a corporation which actually exists both in fact and in law. It has complied with all the requirements of law and therefore its juridical personality is not subject to the direct attack by the state through quo warranto proceedings Statement 2: A de facto corporation refers to a corporation which actually exists for all practical purposes as a corporation but which has no legal right to corporate existence as against the State since it has not complied with all the formalities or requirements provided by law. This corporation has a corporate existence but its juridical personality may be directly attacked by the state through quo warranto proceedings

choices.text: Both statements are true
Only Statement 1 is true
Only Statement 2 is true
Both statements are false

explanation: Both statements correctly define de jure and de facto corporations. A de jure corporation has complied with all legal requirements and cannot be attacked by the state, while a de facto corporation exists in fact but may be attacked by the state for non-compliance with legal requirements.

text: Statement 1: Persons who have agreed to take and pay for original unissued shares of a corporation formed or to be formed are called subscribers Statement 2: Persons who bring about or cause to bring about the formation and organization of a corporation by bringing together the persons interested in the enterprise are called promoters

choices.text: Both statements are true
Only Statement 1 is true
Only Statement 2 is true
Both statements are false

explanation: Both statements correctly define subscribers and promoters. Subscribers are those who agree to take and pay for unissued shares, while promoters are those who initiate and organize the formation of the corporation.

text: Statement 1: The interest or right of the stockholder in the corporation's profit or in the net assets of corporation on dissolution is shares of stock Statement 2: Certificate of stock refers to the paper representation or tangible evidence of the stock itself and of the various interests therein and expresses the contract between the corporation and the stockholder. It is not actually necessary to render a person a stockholder in a corporation because it is merely evidence of the shares of stock covered

choices.text: Both statements are true
Only Statement 1 is true
Only Statement 2 is true
Both statements are false

explanation: Both statements are correct. Shares of stock represent the stockholder's interest in the corporation's profits and assets, while a certificate of stock is merely the physical evidence of ownership and not necessary to establish stockholder status.

text: Statement 1: Common shares refer to the basic class of ordinary shares usually without extraordinary rights and privileges, and the owners thereof are entitled to pro-rata share in the profits of the corporation and in its assets upon dissolution and likewise in the management of its affairs. This type of shares which has complete voting rights is required to be present in every stock corporation Statement 2: Preferred shares refer to a type of shares of stocks that is issued with some privileges in the distribution of dividends and net assets of the corporation

choices.text: Both statements are true
Only Statement 1 is true
Only Statement 2 is true
Both statements are false

explanation: Both statements correctly define common and preferred shares. Common shares are the basic shares with voting rights and pro-rata participation in profits and assets, while preferred shares have special privileges in dividend distribution and asset distribution.

text: It refers to a type of shares of stocks issued with an arbitrary amount stated in its certificate of stock. This type of shares of stocks cannot be issued below that said face value appearing in the certificate of stock and stated in the Articles of Incorporation. Preferred stocks must always be classified as this type of stocks while common may or may not be this type of stocks

choices.text: Par value shares
No par value shares
Issued value shares
Present value shares

explanation: Par value shares are shares issued with an arbitrary amount stated in the certificate of stock. This amount serves as the minimum issue price and must be stated in the Articles of Incorporation. Preferred stocks must always be par value shares.

text: Amount equal to the aggregate par value or issued value of the outstanding capital stock

choices.text: Legal capital
Unissued capital stock
Outstanding capital stock
Authorized capital stock

explanation: Outstanding capital stock refers to the total amount of capital stock that has been issued and is currently held by stockholders. It is equal to the aggregate par value or issued value of all shares that have been issued and are not treasury shares.

text: Which of the following statements pertaining to the purpose or purposes of a stock corporation is incorrect?

choices.text: A stock corporation may have more than one purpose
The purposes, if there are several, must be susceptible of being lawfully combined
The primary purpose and the secondary purposes may be stated together as one purpose in the articles of incorporation
The purposes must be lawful

explanation: The primary purpose and secondary purposes must be stated separately in the articles of incorporation. They cannot be combined into one purpose statement.

text: How may a corporation be created under Philippine setting?

choices.text: In case of private corporation, by operation of general corporation law particularly the Revised Corporation Code of the Philippines.
In case of public corporation, by law or enactment of special law.
Either A or B.
By mere consent of the contracting parties

explanation: A corporation can be created either through the Revised Corporation Code for private corporations or through special laws for public corporations. It cannot be created by mere consent of contracting parties.

text: Which of the following corporate legal doctrines is not true?

choices.text: The business judgement rule means that a stockholder is personally liable for the financial obligations of the corporation to the extent only of his unpaid subscription or that a stockholders liability for corporate debts extends only up to the amount of his capital contribution
The doctrine of separate juridical personality means that a corporation is a juridical entity with legal personality separate and distinct from those acting for and, in its behalf

The right of succession or continuity of existence means that the corporation has the capacity for continuous existence despite the death or replacement of its shareholders or members, for it has a personality separate and distinct from those who compose it
The trust fund doctrine means that the capital stock of a corporation or the assets of an insolvent corporation representing its capital is a trust fund reserved for the benefit of companys creditors

explanation: The business judgement rule actually refers to the presumption that directors and officers act in good faith and in the best interests of the corporation. It is not about stockholder liability.

text: Are the stockholders, directors or officers personally liable for the liabilities of the corporation after the assets of the corporation are exhausted?

choices.text: Yes because they are considered to be general partners
No under all instances
Yes under all instances
No as a general rule, unless exceptional cases warrant the piercing of the veil of corporate fiction

explanation: Generally, stockholders, directors, and officers are not personally liable for corporate debts due to the doctrine of limited liability. However, in exceptional cases where the corporate veil is pierced, they may be held personally liable.
