text: What are the exceptional cases wherein the courts may pierce the veil of corporate fiction so that the stockholders, directors or officers will become personally liable for corporate debts?

choices.text: When the corporate entity is used as a mere alter ego, business conduit or instrumentality of a person or another entity
When the corporate entity is used to defeat public convenience such as in case of labor case
When the corporate entity is used to commit fraud or to justify a wrong or to defend a crime or to commit tax evasion
Any of the above

explanation: All the given scenarios are valid grounds for piercing the corporate veil. The courts may pierce the veil when the corporation is used as an alter ego, to defeat public convenience, or to commit fraud or other illegal acts.

text: Statement 1: A corporation by prescription is a corporation which has acquired its corporate existence through long and continued use of corporate powers Statement 2: A corporation by estoppel is a corporation which has no juridical personality but is considered as a corporation in relation to those who deal with it in good faith

choices.text: Both statements are true
Only Statement 1 is true
Only Statement 2 is true
Both statements are false

explanation: Both statements correctly define corporations by prescription and estoppel. A corporation by prescription acquires its existence through long use of corporate powers, while a corporation by estoppel has no juridical personality but is treated as a corporation for those dealing with it in good faith.

text: Under the Revised Corporation Code, what is the requirement for the issuance of preferred shares?

choices.text: Preferred shares of stock must be issued with par value
Preferred shares of stock may either be par value shares or no-par value shares
Preferred shares of stock must be no-par value shares
Preferred shares of stock may be issued only with discounted value

explanation: Under the Revised Corporation Code, preferred shares must be issued with par value. This is a mandatory requirement to ensure proper valuation and protection of preferred shareholders' rights.

text: What is/are the means by which the issue price of no par value common value shares is determined?

choices.text: It may be fixed by the Board of Directors based on the authority given in the articles of incorporation
It may be fixed in the articles of incorporation or by-laws
It may be fixed by stockholders representing at least a majority of the outstanding capital stock at a meeting duly called for the purpose
Any of the above

explanation: The issue price of no par value common shares can be determined through any of the given methods: by the Board of Directors, in the articles of incorporation or by-laws, or by majority vote of stockholders at a duly called meeting.

text: Which is correct as regards to legal capital of par-value shares of stocks and no-par value shares of stocks?

choices.text: In case of par-value shares of stocks, the legal capital is the total par value of shares issued and subscribed
In case of no par-value shares of stocks, the legal capital is the entire consideration received
Both A and B
Neither A nor B

explanation: Both statements are correct. For par-value shares, legal capital is the total par value of issued and subscribed shares. For no-par value shares, legal capital is the entire consideration received for the shares.

text: If founders share classified as such in the Articles of Incorporation is given exclusive right to vote and be voted in the election of the board of directors, what is the maximum period or limit of that right?

choices.text: 2 years from the approval of SEC
3 years from the approval of SEC
5 years from the approval of SEC
10 years from the approval of SEC

explanation: The maximum period for exclusive voting rights of founders shares is 5 years from SEC approval. This limitation prevents perpetual control by founders and promotes corporate democracy.

text: Which of the following statements refers to the authorized capital stock?

choices.text: It refers to the portion of the capital stock or total shares of stock issued to subscribers or stockholders, whether fully paid or partially paid, except treasury shares. It pertains to capital stock entitled to dividends or right to vote
It refers to the total amount of the capital that persons have agreed to take and pay for, which need not necessarily be, and can be more than, the par value of the shares
It refers to the amount fixed in the articles of incorporation that may be subscribed and paid by the stockholders of the corporation

It refers to the amount equal to the aggregate par value of total shares issued and subscribed in case of par value shares or total consideration received in case of no par value shares and it cannot be returned to shareholders until dissolution

explanation: Authorized capital stock is the maximum amount of capital stock that a corporation is authorized to issue as stated in its articles of incorporation. This is the ceiling for the corporation's capital stock.

text: What is the life of a private corporation?

choices.text: It has perpetual existence unless its articles of incorporation provide for a specific term
It has maximum life of 20 years
It has maximum life of 30 years
It has maximum life of 50 years

explanation: Under the Revised Corporation Code, a private corporation has perpetual existence by default. However, the articles of incorporation may provide for a specific term if the incorporators choose to limit its existence.

text: What is the period for renewal of term of a private corporation prior its term expiration?

choices.text: Within a 1-year period
Within a 2-year period
Within a 3-year period
Within a 5-year period

explanation: A private corporation must renew its term within 3 years prior to its expiration. This period allows sufficient time for the renewal process while ensuring the corporation's continuous existence.

text: Under the Revised Corporation Code, may the corporation with a fixed term whose term has expired file an application for revival of certificate of incorporation with SEC?

choices.text: No, because the corporation is ipso facto dissolved by operation of law upon failure to renew the term within the deadline
Yes, a corporation whose term has expired may apply with SEC for the revival of its certificate of incorporation and subject to all of its duties, debts, and liabilities existing prior to its revival
No, in the absence of court order
Yes, but only with the consent of the Congress of the Philippines

explanation: Under the Revised Corporation Code, a corporation with an expired term may apply for revival with the SEC. The revival will be subject to all existing duties, debts, and liabilities that existed prior to the revival.

text: What is the implied minimum authorized capital stock of an ordinary stock corporation?

choices.text: None

explanation: The Revised Corporation Code does not prescribe a minimum authorized capital stock for ordinary stock corporations. The amount is left to the discretion of the incorporators based on their business needs.

text: ABC Inc. has an authorized capital stock of P60,000. Which of the following comply with the capital requirements of law for valid incorporation?

choices.text: has an authorized capital stock of P60,000. Which of the following comply with the capital requirements of law for valid incorporation?
Actual subscription of P24,000 and paid up capital of P5,200
Actual subscription of P12,000 and paid up capital of P5,000
Actual subscription of P15,000 and paid up capital of P3,750

explanation: All the given options comply with the capital requirements. The law requires at least 25% of the authorized capital stock to be subscribed and at least 25% of the subscribed capital to be paid up. All options meet these minimum requirements.

text: Statement 1 Certificate of incorporation or registration refers to the document issued by the SEC to a newly formed corporation which evidenced the existence of the juridical personality of the corporation. It is also known as the primary franchise of a corporation Statement 2 By-laws refer to the document that defines the charter of relationships between the State and the corporation, the stockholder and the State, and between the corporation and its stockholders. It must be submitted to Securities and Exchange Commission SEC by the incorporators in order for the proposed corporation to obtain its juridical personality Statement 3 Articles of Incorporation refer to the rules of action adopted by a corporation for its internal government and for the regulation of conduct, and it prescribes the rights and duties of its stockholders or members towards itself and among themselves in reference to the management of its affairs

choices.text: All statements are true
Only one statement is true
Only two statements are true
All statements are false

explanation: Only Statement 1 is correct. Statement 2 incorrectly describes by-laws (it actually describes the articles of incorporation), and Statement 3 incorrectly describes articles of incorporation (it actually describes by-laws).

text: Which is the primary government agency authorized to approve or reject the amendment in the articles of incorporation of a corporation?

choices.text: Securities and Exchange Commission
Department of Trade and Industry
Bureau of Internal Revenue
Department of Finance

explanation: The Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) is the primary government agency authorized to approve or reject amendments to the articles of incorporation. This is part of its regulatory function over corporations.

text: Under Revised Corporation Code, for primary registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the following are the documents to be submitted by the proponents for the creation of domestic stock corporation, except

choices.text: Cover Sheet for Registration
Articles of Incorporation
By-Laws
Treasurers Affidavit showing the compliance with minimum subscription and paid-up capital including the certificate of deposit and letter of authority to examine bank deposit

explanation: The Treasurer's Affidavit is not required for primary registration. The required documents are the Cover Sheet for Registration, Articles of Incorporation, and By-Laws.

text: The purpose clause must specify the corporations primary purpose and which are secondary which need not be related to the main purpose. The significance or reasons of purpose clause in the articles of incorporation are as follows, except

choices.text: It confers as well as limits the powers which a corporation may exercise
It informs prospective investors and creditors of the kind of business the corporation deals with
It notifies the management of the limits of its actions
It allows the corporation to engage in any type of business or transactions

explanation: The purpose clause actually limits the corporation's activities to those specified in its articles of incorporation. It does not allow the corporation to engage in any type of business or transactions.

text: When a change in the corporate name is approved, the SEC shall issue an amended certificate of incorporation under the amended name. What is the effect of the mere change of the corporate name approved by SEC?

choices.text: It will result to dissolution of the previous corporation
It results to the creation of a new corporation
It has no effect on the identity of the corporation, or on its property, rights or liabilities
It will extinguish all the liabilities of the said corporation

explanation: A mere change in corporate name does not affect the corporation's identity, property, rights, or liabilities. The corporation remains the same juridical entity, only its name is changed.

text: When does a private corporation formed under the Revised Corporation Code obtain its corporate existence or juridical personality?

choices.text: From the date of consent of the incorporators to the articles of incorporation
From the date of submission of the articles of incorporation to the SEC
From the date of submission of the by-laws to the SEC
From the date of issuance by the SEC of the certificate of incorporation under SECs official seal

explanation: A private corporation obtains its juridical personality only upon the issuance of the certificate of incorporation by the SEC under its official seal. This is the moment when the corporation becomes a legal entity.

text: What is the effect if a corporation does not formally organize and commence the transaction of its business or the construction of its works within five (5) years from the date of its incorporation or issuance of certificate of registration by SEC under SECs official seal for causes within the corporations control?

choices.text: The corporation is ipso facto dissolved by operation of law
That shall be a non-automatic ground for suspension or revocation of corporate charter or corporate dissolution making such entity a de facto corporation
The corporation is considered de facto corporation
The corporation shall be criminally liable

explanation: If a corporation fails to organize and commence business within 5 years from incorporation for causes within its control, it is automatically dissolved by operation of law.

text: What is the effect if a corporation has commenced the transaction of its business five (5) years from the date of its incorporation but subsequently becomes continuously inoperative for a period of at least five (5) years?

choices.text: The corporation is ipso facto dissolved by operation of law
That shall be a non-automatic ground for suspension or revocation of corporate charter or corporate dissolution making such entity a delinquent corporation
The corporation is considered an ostensible corporation
The corporation shall be criminally liable

explanation: If a corporation becomes continuously inoperative for at least 5 years after commencing business, it becomes a delinquent corporation, which is a ground for suspension or revocation of its corporate charter.

text: What is the policy-making or governing body of a private corporation?

choices.text: General partners
Board of Directors/Trustees
General manager
Council of elders

explanation: The Board of Directors (for stock corporations) or Board of Trustees (for non-stock corporations) is the policy-making and governing body of a private corporation. They are responsible for making major corporate decisions and overseeing the corporation's management.

text: The following are the qualifications of directors of a stock corporation, except

choices.text: He must own at least one share of the capital stock of the corporation
He must be of legal age
They must not be more than 15 directors
All of the above are qualifications of directors

explanation: All the options listed are actually qualifications of directors: ownership of at least one share, being of legal age, and the maximum number of directors being 15. Therefore, none of them are exceptions to the qualifications.

text: Under the Revised Corporation Code, what is minimum number of Independent Directors in corporations vested with public interest?

choices.text: At least 10% of the directors
At least 13% of the directors
At least 20% of the directors
At least 25% of the directors

explanation: Under the Revised Corporation Code, corporations vested with public interest must have at least 20% of their board composed of independent directors to ensure proper corporate governance and protection of public interest.

text: What is the maximum term of office of directors of a stock corporation?

choices.text: Term of three years but he may continue to serve until their successors are elected and qualified
Term of four years but he may continue to serve until their successors are elected and qualified
Term of two years but he may continue to serve until their successors are elected and qualified
Term of one year but he may continue to serve until their successors are elected and qualified

explanation: Directors of a stock corporation serve for a maximum term of three years, but they may continue to serve until their successors are elected and qualified to ensure continuity in corporate management.

text: Which of the following statements concerning number of directors/trustees of a corporation is false?

choices.text: Trustees of nonstock educational corporation shall be 5 or 10 or 15
In a one person corporation, the number of directors is at least 5
In a stock corporation, it must not be more than 15
In ordinary non-stock corporation, the board of trustees may exceed 15 members

explanation: This statement is false because in a one person corporation (OPC), there is only one director who is the single stockholder. The other statements are correct regarding the number of directors/trustees in different types of corporations.

text: Statement 1 Cumulative voting is defined as a method of concentrating votes devised to give sufficient opportunity to minority shareholders to secure representation in the board. It is the manner of voting required by the Revised Corporation Code for election of board of directors in a stock corporation Statement 2 Straight voting is defined as method of voting wherein a member can only cast one vote per share for each director

choices.text: It is the manner of voting required by the Revised Corporation Code for election of board of directors in a stock corporation Statement 2 Straight voting is defined as method of voting wherein a member can only cast one vote per share for each director
Only Statement 2 is true
Only Statement 1 is true
Both statements are true

explanation: Both statements correctly define cumulative voting and straight voting. Cumulative voting allows minority shareholders to concentrate their votes to secure board representation, while straight voting limits each share to one vote per director.

text: It is the manner of voting for election of board of trustees in a non-stock corporation

choices.text: Straight voting
Members of non-stock corporations may cast as many votes as there are trustees elected but may cast not more than one vote for one candidate
Cumulative voting by distribution
Cumulative voting for one candidate

explanation: In non-stock corporations, members can cast as many votes as there are trustees to be elected, but they cannot cast more than one vote for any single candidate. This ensures fair representation while preventing concentration of power.

text: Which of the following statements concerning the election of directors/trustees is false?

choices.text: At any meeting of stockholder or members called for the election of directors or trustees, there must be present either in person or by representative authorized to act by written proxy, the owners of a majority of the outstanding capital stock or majority of members entitled to vote
The election must be by ballot if requested by any voting member or stockholder
The candidates receiving the higher number of votes shall be declared elected and a majority vote is not necessary as long as there is a quorum during the election
Delinquent stocks may be voted

explanation: Delinquent stocks cannot be voted. The other statements are correct regarding the election process: requirement for majority presence, ballot voting if requested, and election by plurality vote with quorum.

text: What is the number of vote of each director of a corporation regarding act of management or administration?

choices.text: It is dependent upon the stocks owned by a director
Five votes for each director
One vote for each director
None

explanation: Each director has one vote in matters of management or administration, regardless of the number of shares they own. This ensures equal participation in corporate decision-making.

text: Statement 1 Under the Revised Corporation Code, the period for reporting to SEC of non-holding of elections of directors/trustees and the reasons therefore is within 30 days from the date of the scheduled election Statement 2 Under the Revised Corporation Code, the latest period for the holding of new election in case of non-holding of elections of directors/trustees shall not be later than 60 days from the scheduled date or original date

choices.text: Only Statement 1 is true
Only Statement 2 is true
Both statements are true
Both statements are false

explanation: Both statements are correct. The SEC must be notified within 30 days of non-holding of elections, and new elections must be held within 60 days of the original date.

text: When may the courts exceptionally interfere to the contracts entered into by the board of directors?

choices.text: When the contracts are so unconscionable and oppressive as to amount to a wanton destruction of rights of the minority
When the contracts are considered ultra vires
Neither A nor B
Either A or B

explanation: Courts may interfere with board contracts in two exceptional cases: when the contracts are unconscionable and oppressive to minority rights, or when the contracts are ultra vires (beyond the corporation's powers). Both situations warrant judicial intervention.

text: The following are the mandatory corporate officers under the Revised Corporation Code, except

choices.text: Treasurer who has the authority to receive and keep funds of the corporation and to disburse them in accordance with the authority given to him by Board of authorized officers
Secretary who is regarded as the custodian of corporate records
President who is regarded as the highest executive officer in the corporate settings and necessarily brings with him implied powers and apparent authority of the corporation
All of the above are mandatory corporate officers

explanation: All the officers listed (Treasurer, Secretary, and President) are mandatory corporate officers under the Revised Corporation Code. Each has specific roles and responsibilities in the corporation's operations.

text: The following are the qualifications of a corporate president, except

choices.text: He must neither be a secretary nor a treasurer of the same corporation
He must be a resident citizen of the Philippines
He must be a stockholder of the corporation
He must be a director of the corporation

explanation: A corporate president is not required to be a stockholder of the corporation. The other options are correct: the president cannot be the secretary or treasurer, must be a resident citizen of the Philippines, and must be a director.

text: What is the qualification of a corporate treasurer?

choices.text: Must be resident-citizen of the Philippines
Must be a stockholder and must be a Filipino Citizen
Not the corporate president and must be a resident of the Philippines
Must be a stockholder and a Director

explanation: A corporate treasurer must be a resident of the Philippines and cannot be the corporate president. Unlike the president, the treasurer is not required to be a stockholder or director of the corporation.

text: Under the Revised Corporation Code, which of the following is/are considered temporary grounds for disqualification of directors, trustees or corporate officers for a period of at least five (5) years?

choices.text: Found administratively liable for any offense involving fraudulent acts
By a foreign court or equivalent foreign regulatory for acts, violations or misconduct similar to those enumerate in letter b and c above
Convicted by final judgment of an offense punishable by imprisonment for a period exceeding six (6) years, violation of Revised Corporation Code, and violation of Securities Regulation Code
All of the above

explanation: All the listed grounds are temporary disqualifications that prevent a person from serving as a director, trustee, or corporate officer for at least five years. These include administrative liability for fraud, foreign court judgments, and certain criminal convictions.

text: Under Revised Corporation Code, when shall the election to fill-up vacancy in the board of directors/trustees be held if the reason is for causes other than the expiration of term removal, increase in sits, resignation, abandonment of office, or death?

choices.text: It shall be held no later than 15 days from the time the vacancy arose
It shall be held no later than 20 days from the time the vacancy arose
It shall be held no later than 45 days from the time the vacancy arose
It shall be held no later than 30 days from the time the vacancy arose

explanation: Under the Revised Corporation Code, when a vacancy occurs in the board for reasons other than expiration of term, removal, increase in seats, resignation, abandonment, or death, the election to fill the vacancy must be held within 30 days from when the vacancy arose.

text: The following are the reasons for board vacancy which will disqualify the remaining members of the board with quorum to fill up the vacancy in the board, except

choices.text: Expiration of term of a director
Disqualification of a director
Removal of a director
Increase in the sits of the board

explanation: An increase in the number of board seats does not disqualify the remaining members from filling vacancies. However, expiration of term, disqualification, and removal of a director are reasons that prevent the remaining board members from filling the vacancy.

text: The Articles of Incorporation and By-Laws provide for a maximum of 15 directors for JD, Inc. During 2021 Statement 1: 3 directors resigned and 4 directors died. The vacancies can be filled up either by plurality vote of the majority of the outstanding capital stock entitled to vote or by majority vote of the remaining members of board of directors Statement 2: 3 directors were removed by stockholders vote and 2 directors term expired. The vacancies can only be filled up by plurality vote of the majority of the outstanding capital stock entitled to vote Statement 3: 2 directors resigned, 2 directors died and 4 directors were disqualified. The vacancies can only be filled up by plurality vote of the majority of the outstanding capital stock entitled to vote

choices.text: During 2021 Statement 1: 3 directors resigned and 4 directors died. The vacancies can be filled up either by plurality vote of the majority of the outstanding capital stock entitled to vote or by majority vote of the remaining members of board of directors Statement 2: 3 directors were removed by stockholders vote and 2 directors term expired. The vacancies can only be filled up by plurality vote of the majority of the outstanding capital stock entitled to vote Statement 3: 2 directors resigned, 2 directors died and 4 directors were disqualified. The vacancies can only be filled up by plurality vote of the majority of the outstanding capital stock entitled to vote
Only one statement is true
Only two statements are true
All statements are true

explanation: Statements 1 and 3 are true. When vacancies are due to resignation or death, they can be filled by either the board or stockholders. However, when vacancies are due to removal, expiration of term, or disqualification, only stockholders can fill the vacancies.

text: Statement 1: As a general rule, directors of a corporation are not entitled to receive any compensation except for reasonable per diems or unless the compensation is fixed by by-laws or when granted by the vote of stockholders Statement 2: The maximum amount to be granted as compensation to board of directors in such capacity is 10% of the net income of corporation before tax of the immediately preceding year

choices.text: Only Statement 1 is true
Only Statement 2 is true
Both statements are true
Both statements are false

explanation: Both statements are correct. Directors are generally not entitled to compensation except for per diems, unless provided in the by-laws or approved by stockholders. Additionally, their compensation is capped at 10% of the corporation's net income before tax from the previous year.

text: What is the liability of a director or officer when he attempts to acquire or acquires, in violation of his duty, any interest adverse to the corporation in respect of any matter which has been reposed in him in confidence?

choices.text: He shall be liable as a trustee for the corporation and must account for the profits which otherwise would have accrued to the corporation
He is not liable to the corporation if the director is the majority stockholder
He shall not be liable to the corporation
He is liable but only to the extent of his capital contribution

text: The following are the remedies of the stockholders in case of mismanagement of the corporation, except

choices.text: Ask for the involuntary dissolution of the corporation if the abuse amounts to a ground for the institution of a quo warranto proceedings but the Solicitor General refuses to act
File a derivative suit with RTC or complaint with the SEC
File an action for receivership
File a criminal action against the corporation e. File an action for injunction if the act has not yet been done

explanation: Stockholders cannot file a criminal action against the corporation itself. The other options are valid remedies: involuntary dissolution, derivative suit, receivership, and injunction. Criminal actions are typically filed by the state, not by stockholders.

text: Statement 1: An independent director refers to a person who, apart from shareholdings and fees received from the corporation, is independent of management and free from any business or other relationship which could, or could reasonably be perceived to materially interfere with the exercise of independent judgment in carrying out the responsibilities as a director Statement 2: A self-dealing director, trustee or officer refers to a director, trustee, or officer who personally contracts with the corporation in which he is director, trustee or officer Statement 3: An interlocking director, trustee or officer refers to a person who is a director, trustee or officer in different corporations

choices.text: Only one statement is true
Only two statements are true
All statements are true
All statements are false

explanation: All three statements correctly define different types of directors. An independent director is free from management influence, a self-dealing director contracts with their own corporation, and an interlocking director serves on multiple corporate boards.

text: The following are the essential requisites in order for a contract entered into by self-dealing director/officer with the corporation to be perfectly valid even without requiring ratification from stockholders, except

choices.text: That the contract is fair and reasonable under the circumstances
That the presence of such self-dealing director in the board meeting in which the contract was approved was necessary to constitute a quorum
In the case of an officer, the contract has been previously authorized by the board of directors
That the vote of the self-dealing director was not necessary for the approval of the contract

explanation: The presence of a self-dealing director is not a requirement for a valid contract. The other options are essential requisites: the contract must be fair and reasonable, previously authorized for officers, and the self-dealing director's vote must not be necessary for approval.

text: What is the status, as a general rule, of a contract entered into by 2 or more corporations, having interlocking directors?

choices.text: Voidable at the option of the director
Voidable at the option of the corporation
Null and void
Valid and without defect provided there is no fraud and the contract is fair and reasonable

explanation: Contracts between corporations with interlocking directors are generally valid if they are fair, reasonable, and free from fraud. The presence of interlocking directors alone does not invalidate the contract.

text: It refers to a body created by the by-laws and composed of not less than three appointed members of the board which, subject to the statutory limitations, has all the authority of the board to the extent provided in the board resolution or by-laws. This body may act, by majority of all its members, on such specific matters within the competence of the board as may be delegated to it in by-laws

choices.text: Executive council
Executive group
Executive body
Executive committee

explanation: An executive committee is a body created by by-laws with at least three board members. It has the authority to act on specific matters delegated to it by the board, subject to statutory limitations and the terms of its creation.

text: How may an executive committee be created?

choices.text: The executive committee can be created by the board of directors itself through a simple board resolution even if nothing is stated in the by-laws regarding its creation
The executive committee can only be created by virtue of a provision in the by-laws
Either A or B
Neither A nor B

explanation: An executive committee can only be created through a provision in the by-laws. The board of directors cannot create it through a simple resolution without by-law authorization.

text: The following are examples of implied or necessary powers of a private corporation, except

choices.text: To establish a local post office by a mining company
To issue checks
To sell, supply or manage advertising materials for an advertising company
To operate an online casino for a company engaged in amusement center for various computer games e. To operate power plant for cement factory company

explanation: Operating an online casino is not an implied or necessary power for a company engaged in amusement centers. The other options are examples of implied powers that are reasonably necessary for the corporation's business.

text: The following are examples of incidental or inherent powers of a private corporation, except

choices.text: Right to succession
Right to have corporate name
Right to make by-laws for its government
All of the above are incidental or inherent powers

explanation: All the options listed (right to succession, right to have corporate name, and right to make by-laws) are incidental or inherent powers that arise from the corporation's nature as a juridical person.

text: Statement 1: An ultra vires act refers to act committed outside the object for which a corporation is created as defined by the law of its organization and therefore beyond the express, implied and incidental powers of the corporation Statement 2: The status of ultra vires contracts entered by a corporation which are illegal per se such as crime are null and void

choices.text: Only Statement 1 is true
Only Statement 2 is true
Both statements are true
Both statements are false

explanation: Both statements are correct. An ultra vires act is one beyond the corporation's powers, and contracts that are illegal per se (like criminal activities) are null and void regardless of whether they are ultra vires or not.

text: Statement 1: Pre-emptive right refers to the right of shareholders to subscribe to all issues or disposition of shares of any class in proportion to their present shareholdings in order to preserve their ownership interest in the corporation unless properly denied in the articles of incorporation. It is intended to protect both the proprietary and voting rights of a stockholder in a corporation, since such proportionate interest determines his proportionate power to vote in corporate affairs when the law gives the shareholders a right to affirm or deny board actions. It is a common law right which may be exercised by stockholders even when no provision is stated in the law Statement 2: Right of first refusal provides that a stockholder who may wish to sell or assign his shares must first offer the shares to the corporation or to other existing stockholders of the corporation, under terms and conditions which are reasonable and that only when the corporation or the other stockholders do not or fail to exercise their option, is the offering stockholder at liberty to dispose of his shares to third parties. It arises only by virtue of contractual stipulations in which case the right is construed strictly against the right of persons to dispose of or deal with their property. It is normally available in a close corporation as stated in its articles of incorporation as a type of transfer restriction

choices.text: Only Statement 1 is true
Only Statement 2 is true
Both statements are true
Both statements are false

explanation: Both statements correctly define pre-emptive rights and right of first refusal. Pre-emptive rights protect shareholders' proportional ownership and voting rights, while right of first refusal is a contractual right that gives existing shareholders priority in purchasing shares being sold.

text: In which document shall the denial of pre-emptive right of a stockholder be stated for denial to be valid and binding?

choices.text: By-Laws
Articles of incorporation
Neither A nor B
Either A or B

explanation: The denial of pre-emptive rights must be stated in the articles of incorporation to be valid and binding. This is because the articles of incorporation are the primary document that defines the relationship between the corporation and its stockholders.

text: Statement 1: As a general rule and in compliance of trust fund doctrine, dividends can be declared only out of unrestricted retained earnings Statement 2: As a general rule, the maximum surplus profits that can be retained by a stock corporation is 100% of paid up capital

choices.text: Only Statement 1 is true
Only Statement 2 is true
Both statements are true
Both statements are false

explanation: Both statements are correct. Dividends can only be declared from unrestricted retained earnings to protect creditors (trust fund doctrine), and corporations can retain up to 100% of their paid-up capital as surplus profits.

text: Statement 1: Liquidating dividends are dividends which are actually distributions of the assets of the corporation upon dissolution or winding up of the same Statement 2: Stock dividend is an example of dividends required to be ratified by the stockholders owning at least 2/3 of the outstanding capital stock entitled to vote

choices.text: Only Statement 1 is true
Only Statement 2 is true
Both statements are true
Both statements are false

explanation: Both statements are correct. Liquidating dividends are distributions of assets upon dissolution, and stock dividends require ratification by stockholders owning at least 2/3 of the outstanding capital stock.

text: Statement 1: A management contract refers to any contract whereby a corporation undertakes to manage or operate all or substantially all of the business of another corporation, whether such contracts are called service contracts, operating agreements or otherwise Statement 2: As a general rule, the maximum period for one term of management contract is 5 years

choices.text: Only Statement 1 is true
Only Statement 2 is true
Both statements are true
Both statements are false

explanation: Both statements are correct. A management contract involves one corporation managing another's business, and such contracts are limited to a maximum term of 5 years to prevent long-term control by the managing corporation.

text: The following are the purposes of by-laws, except

choices.text: It defines the rights and duties of corporate officers and directors and of stockholders toward the corporation and among themselves
It is a condition precedent before the acquisition of juridical personality of a corporation
It affects and prejudices the interests of third persons
It supplements the articles of incorporation e. It regulates the business transactions of the corporation in a particular way

explanation: By-laws do not affect or prejudice the interests of third persons. They are internal rules that govern the corporation's internal affairs and relationships between the corporation and its stockholders, officers, and directors.

text: The following are the requisites for the validity of by-laws, except

choices.text: It must be discriminatory, oppressive and arbitrary
It must not impair obligations and contracts
It must not be contrary to the Revised Corporation Code, any law, and Articles of Incorporation
It must not be contrary to morals and public policy

explanation: By-laws must NOT be discriminatory, oppressive, or arbitrary. They must be fair and reasonable, and cannot violate laws, impair contracts, or be contrary to morals and public policy.

text: Under Revised Corporation Code, what is the new mode of giving notice to stockholders/members regarding their regular or special meetings? a. It may now be sent through the use of pigeons

choices.text: It may now be sent through the use of pigeons
It may now be sent through the use of animals
It may now be sent electronically (electronic mail or other manner) in accordance with the rules and regulations of the SEC on the use of electronic data messages
All of the above

explanation: The Revised Corporation Code allows electronic notices to be sent to stockholders/members in accordance with SEC rules and regulations on electronic data messages. This modernizes the notice requirement while ensuring proper delivery.

text: Under Revised Corporation Code, when may notice of meetings to stockholders/members be allowed to be given to them electronically in accordance with the rules and regulations of the SEC on the use of electronic data messages?

choices.text: When electronic sending is done with the consent of stockholders or members
When electronic sending is allowed in the by-laws
Neither A nor B
Either A or B

explanation: Electronic notices are allowed either when the stockholders/members consent to it or when it is allowed in the by-laws. This provides flexibility while ensuring proper notice to all concerned parties.

text: Under Revised Corporation Code, if a date is not fixed in the by-laws for the regular meeting of shareholders or members, when shall the regular shareholders or members meeting be held?

choices.text: On any date after May 15 as determined by Board of Directors or Trustees
On any date after July 15 as determined by Board of Directors or Trustees
On any date after April 15 as determined by Board of Directors or Trustees
On any date after June 15 as determined by Board of Directors or Trustees

explanation: If no date is fixed in the by-laws, the regular meeting must be held on any date after April 15 as determined by the Board of Directors or Trustees. This ensures that annual meetings are held within a reasonable timeframe.

text: Mandatorily, where shall the regular and special meeting of stockholders be located?

choices.text: In the city/municipality where the principal warehouse is located preferably at the principal warehouse of the corporation
In the city/municipality where the largest branch is located preferably at the largest branch of the corporation
In the city/municipality where the principal office is located preferably at the principal office of the corporation
In the city/municipality where the principal branch is located preferably at the principal branch office of the corporation

explanation: Stockholders' meetings must be held in the city/municipality where the corporation's principal office is located, preferably at that office. This ensures accessibility and proper venue for corporate meetings.

text: Statement 1: In case the by-laws is silent, the regular meeting of stockholders shall be held annually Statement 2: In case the by-laws is silent, the regular meeting of board of directors shall be held monthly

choices.text: Only Statement 1 is true
Only Statement 2 is true
Both statements are true
Both statements are false

explanation: Both statements are correct. When the by-laws are silent, stockholders must meet annually, and the board of directors must meet monthly. These are default requirements under the Revised Corporation Code.

text: Statement 1: In case the by-laws is silent, the President has the authority to order the calling of regular and special meeting of board of directors and regular meeting of stockholders Statement 2: In case the by-laws is silent, the Chairman of the Board shall preside the regular meeting of board of directors or regular meeting of shareholders Statement 3: In case the by-laws is silent, the Secretary has the obligation to call the regular and special meeting of board of directors or regular meeting of stockholders after being properly authorized

choices.text: Only one statement is true
Only two statements are true
All statements are true
All statements are false

explanation: All three statements are correct. The President can call meetings, the Chairman presides over them, and the Secretary has the duty to call meetings when authorized. These are default rules when the by-laws are silent.

text: Under Revised Corporation Code, in case the by-laws is silent, what is the minimum number of days of giving notice in case of meeting of stockholders or board of directors? Regular meeting of stockholders Special meeting of stockholders Meeting of Directors

choices.text: At least two weeks At least one week At least one day
At least three days At least two days At least five days
At least 21 days At least one week At least two days
At least four days At least five days At least six days

explanation: When the by-laws are silent, the minimum notice periods are: 21 days for regular stockholders' meetings, one week for special stockholders' meetings, and two days for board meetings. These periods ensure adequate time for preparation and attendance.

text: In case the by-laws is silent, where shall the meeting of the board of directors be held?

choices.text: In the principal office of the corporation
In the principal operation of the corporation
Anywhere provided within the Philippines
Anywhere in or out of the Philippines

explanation: When the by-laws are silent, board meetings must be held at the corporation's principal office. This ensures a consistent and accessible location for board meetings.

text: In which meeting is proxy allowed?

choices.text: Meeting of shareholders/members
Meeting of board of directors/trustees
Both A and B
Neither A or B

explanation: Proxy voting is only allowed in meetings of shareholders/members. Directors/trustees must attend board meetings in person and cannot be represented by proxy, as they are required to exercise their judgment directly.

text: The following shares are not entitled to vote, except

choices.text: Delinquent shares
Unpaid subscribed shares not yet declared delinquent
Treasury shares
Fractional shares e. Escrow shares before the fulfillment of suspensive condition

explanation: Unpaid subscribed shares that are not yet declared delinquent are entitled to vote. All other options (delinquent shares, treasury shares, fractional shares, and escrow shares before condition fulfillment) are not entitled to vote.

text: Statement 1: A proxy refers to a written authorization given by one person to another so that the second can act for the first and it also refers to the holder of authority or person authorized by an absent stockholder or member to vote for him at a stockholders meeting Statement 2: A voting trust agreement refers to the agreement whereby stockholders (trustors) of a stock corporation confers upon a trustee the right to vote and other rights pertaining to the shares and it should not be used to circumvent the law against monopolies and illegal combinations in restraint of trade or for fraud purposes. It may be pre-terminated through a court petition by the trustors when their rights are trampled upon by the trustee

choices.text: Only Statement 1 is true
Only Statement 2 is true
Both statements are true
Both statements are false

explanation: Both statements correctly define proxy and voting trust agreement. A proxy is a temporary authorization to vote, while a voting trust agreement is a more permanent arrangement that transfers voting rights to a trustee, subject to legal limitations and potential court intervention.

text: The following are the requisites for validity of proxy, except

choices.text: It shall be filed before the scheduled meeting with the corporate secretary
It shall be valid only for the meeting which is was intended unless the proxy is a continuing proxy
It shall be in writing
It shall be valid and effective even for a period longer than 10 years at any one time e. It shall be signed by the shareholder/member concerned

explanation: A proxy cannot be valid for more than 10 years at any one time. The other options are valid requirements: filing with the secretary, meeting-specific validity (unless continuing), written form, and proper signature.

text: Statement 1: The effectivity or validity period of a proxy at any one time is for a period not exceeding 5 years Statement 2: The effectivity and validity period of voting trust agreement at any one time with the exception of voting trust specifically required as a condition in a loan agreement whose period depends upon the term of the loan is for a period not exceeding 5 years

choices.text: Only Statement 1 is true
Only Statement 2 is true
Both statements are true
Both statements are false

explanation: Both statements are correct. Both proxies and voting trust agreements are limited to 5 years, except for voting trusts required by loan agreements which can match the loan term. This prevents indefinite delegation of voting rights.

text: The following are the correct differences between proxy and voting trust agreement, except

choices.text: There is no transfer of title to proxy while there is transfer of title to trustee
All of the above are differences between proxy and voting trust agreement
Proxy need not be notarized while voting trust agreement need to be notarized
The proxy must vote in person while the trustee may vote in person or by proxy

explanation: All the options listed are actually valid differences between proxies and voting trust agreements. The proxy is temporary with no title transfer and no notarization required, while a voting trust involves title transfer, requires notarization, and allows the trustee to vote by proxy.

text: How may a stockholder or member vote in election of directors or trustees of a corporation?

choices.text: By personal voting
Through a proxy
By remote communication or in absentia
Any of the above

explanation: A stockholder or member may vote in any of these ways: in person, through a proxy, or by remote communication/absentia voting. The Revised Corporation Code allows flexibility in voting methods to encourage participation.

text: It refers to any contract for the subscription or acquisition of unissued stock in an existing corporation or the shares of the corporation still to be formed

choices.text: Promotion contract
Acquisition contract
Sales contract
Subscription contract

explanation: A subscription contract is an agreement to take and pay for unissued shares in an existing corporation or shares in a corporation to be formed. It creates a binding obligation to purchase the shares.

text: It refers to a stock issued for a consideration less than their par or issued price

choices.text: Gaseous stock
Secret reserves
Watered stock
Solidified shares

explanation: Watered stock refers to shares issued for consideration less than their par value or issue price. This practice can misrepresent the corporation's actual capital and potentially defraud creditors.

text: The following are the possible effects of watered stocks, except

choices.text: The total assets of the corporation are overstated
The total contributed capital of the corporation is understated
The total stockholders equity of the corporation is overstated
The total liability of the corporation is understated

explanation: Watered stock does not affect the corporation's liabilities. The other options are correct effects: assets are overstated, contributed capital is understated, and stockholders' equity is overstated due to the discrepancy between stated and actual value.

text: Which of the following statements concerning shares of stocks is incorrect?

choices.text: It constitutes intangible personal property of the shareholder
It represents an inchoate interest or a sheer expectancy of a right in the management of the corporation and to share in the profits and net assets of the corporation after payment of corporate debts
It represents proprietary right of stockholder to the assets of the corporation or proprietary claim of co-ownership in the assets of the corporation
It represents aliquot parts of the corporations capital and this interest is indirect, contingent, remote, conjectural, consequential and collateral

explanation: This statement is incorrect because shares of stock do not give stockholders direct proprietary rights to corporate assets. Stockholders have an indirect interest in the corporation's assets through their shares, but no direct ownership claim.

text: Statement 1: A derivative suit refers to a suit brought by one or more stockholders or members in the name and on behalf of the corporation to redress wrongs committed against it or to protect or vindicate corporate rights, whenever the officials of the corporation refuse to sue or are the ones to be sued or hold control of the corporation. The corporation is a necessary party to the suit. It is a suit filed by a person who must be a shareholder to enforce a corporations cause of action Statement 2: An individual suit is an action brought by a stockholder against the corporation for direct violation of his contractual rights Statement 3: A representative suit refers to an action brought by a person in his own behalf or on behalf of all similarly situated

choices.text: Only one statement is true
Only two statements are true
All statements are true
All statements are false

explanation: All three statements correctly define different types of suits. A derivative suit is brought on behalf of the corporation, an individual suit is for direct violations of stockholder rights, and a representative suit is brought on behalf of a class of similarly situated persons.

text: When may a corporation charge an interest on unpaid subscription not yet declared delinquent?

choices.text: From the date of subscription regardless of provision in the by-laws and subscription contract
Only from the moment there is judicial or extrajudicial demand

text: Under the Revised Corporation Code, what is the interest rate on unpaid subscription?

choices.text: Legal interest rate
Market rate
Rate of interest fixed in the subscription contract or legal interest rate in the absence of rate fixed in the subscription contract
Rate of interest fixed in the by-laws or legal interest rate in the absence of rate fixed in the by-laws

explanation: The interest rate on unpaid subscriptions is determined by the subscription contract if specified, or by the legal interest rate if not specified in the contract. The by-laws are not the primary source for determining the interest rate.

text: How many days shall lapse from the due date fixed in the subscription contract or from the date fixed in the call made by the Board of Directors for the shares to be delinquent if still unpaid?

choices.text: 20 days
15 days
30 days
60 days

explanation: Under the Revised Corporation Code, shares become delinquent if unpaid within 30 days from the due date specified in the subscription contract or from the date fixed in the call made by the Board of Directors.

text: Who shall be considered the highest bidder in a delinquency sale/public auction?

choices.text: The person participating in the delinquency sale who offers to pay the full amount of the balance of the subscription together with the accrued interest, costs of advertisement and expenses of sale, for the highest number of shares

The person participating in the delinquency sale who offers to pay the full amount of the balance of the subscription excluding the accrued interest, costs of advertisement and expenses of sale, for the smallest number of shares

The person participating in the delinquency sale who offers to pay the full amount of the balance of the subscription together with the accrued interest, costs of advertisement and expenses of sale, for the smallest number of shares

The person participating in the delinquency sale who offers to pay the full amount of the balance of the subscription excluding the accrued interest, costs of advertisement and expenses of sale, for the highest number of shares

explanation: The highest bidder is determined by who offers to pay the full amount (including interest and expenses) for the highest number of shares. This ensures maximum recovery for the corporation while maintaining fairness in the auction process.

text: The rights of delinquent shareholder are suspended at the time of delinquency. What right is still available to a delinquent shareholder?

choices.text: Right to cash dividends to be offsetted to his balance and right to stock dividends which will be withheld until full payment of the subscription balance
Right to inspect corporate books
Right to vote at stockholders meeting
Right to exercise appraisal right

explanation: A delinquent shareholder retains the right to receive cash dividends (which will be offset against their unpaid balance) and stock dividends (which will be withheld until full payment). All other rights are suspended during delinquency.

text: The following are the property rights of a shareholder, except

choices.text: To transfer of stock in the corporate book
To receive dividends when declared by board of directors
To issuance of certificate of stock/other evidence of stock ownership
All of the above are property rights of a shareholder

explanation: All the options listed are actually property rights of a shareholder: the right to transfer stock, receive dividends, and obtain stock certificates. Therefore, none of them are exceptions to the property rights.

text: The following are the books or records to be kept by the corporation, except

choices.text: Annual financial statements
Book of minutes of all meetings
Stock and transfer book in case of stock corporation
All of the above are books or records to be kept by the corporation

explanation: All the options listed are required books and records that corporations must maintain: annual financial statements, minutes of meetings, and stock and transfer books (for stock corporations). Therefore, none of them are exceptions to the required records.

text: Statement 1: Under the Revised Corporation Code, unless the by-laws provide for a longer period, the stock and transfer book or membership shall be closed at least twenty (20) days before the scheduled date of the regular meeting of stockholders Statement 2: Under the Revised Corporation Code, unless the by-laws provide for a longer period, the stock and transfer book or membership shall be closed at least seven (7) days before the scheduled date of the special meeting

choices.text: Only Statement 1 is true
Only Statement 2 is true
Both statements are true
Both statements are false

explanation: Both statements are correct. The stock and transfer book must be closed 20 days before regular meetings and 7 days before special meetings, unless the by-laws provide for a longer period. This ensures proper determination of voting rights.

text: Under the Revised Corporation Code, unless changed by Department of Finance Secretary, how much is the total assets or total liabilities of the corporation for the financial statements to be required to be audited by CPA?

choices.text: At least P1,000,000 of total assets or total liabilities
At least P500,000 of total assets or total liabilities
At least P600,000 of total assets or total liabilities
At least P100,000 of total assets or total liabilities

explanation: Under the Revised Corporation Code, corporations with total assets or total liabilities of at least P600,000 are required to have their financial statements audited by a CPA, unless the Department of Finance Secretary changes this threshold.

text: Statement 1: Consolidation refers to a business combination whereby one or more existing corporations are absorbed by another corporation which survives and continues the combined business Statement 2: Merger refers to a business combination whereby two or more existing corporations form a new corporation different from the combining corporation

choices.text: Only Statement 1 is true
Only Statement 2 is true
Both statements are true
Both statements are false

explanation: Both statements are incorrect. Consolidation is when two or more corporations form a new corporation, while merger is when one corporation absorbs another. The statements have the definitions reversed.

text: Which of the following is not a requisite for merger or consolidation?

choices.text: There must be ratification by vote of stockholders representing at least 2/3 of outstanding capital stock or members
There must be approval by the Securities and Exchange Commission
It must be approved by the board of directors of each corporation by at least majority vote
All of the above are requisites for merger or consolidation

explanation: All the options listed are actually requisites for merger or consolidation: 2/3 stockholder approval, SEC approval, and majority board approval. Therefore, none of them are exceptions to the requirements.

text: It refers to the right to demand payment of the fair value of his shares, after dissenting from a proposed corporate action involving a fundamental change in the corporation in the cases provided by law. This right may be waived by a shareholder if he has done so knowingly and intelligently

choices.text: Pactum right
Demandable right
Pre-emptive right
Appraisal right

explanation: Appraisal right is the right of a stockholder to demand payment of the fair value of their shares when they dissent from certain fundamental corporate actions. This right can be waived if done knowingly and intelligently.

text: Statement 1: The period for making a written demand on the corporation by a dissenting stockholder for the exercise of his appraisal rights is within 30 days after the date on which the vote was taken Statement 2: The period for submission of certificate of stocks to the corporation for notation as being dissenting stocks in the exercise of appraisal right by a stockholder is within 10 days from his written demand to withdraw

choices.text: Only Statement 1 is true
Only Statement 2 is true
Both statements are true
Both statements are false

explanation: Both statements are correct. A dissenting stockholder must make a written demand within 30 days after the vote, and must submit their stock certificates for notation within 10 days from their written demand to withdraw.

text: The following are the effects of exercise of appraisal right, except

choices.text: All rights accruing to such shares shall be suspended from time of demand for payment of the fair value of the shares until either the abandonment of the corporate action
